headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Reynolds American First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. Now I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Morris Moore, Vic
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Reynolds American First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
Now I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Morris Moore, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the first quarter and our outlook for the full year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management believes this provides better p
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the first quarter and our outlook for the full year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management believes this provides better perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release, which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com. 
Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO.
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you read in today's report, Reynolds American got off to an excellent start this year with sharply higher earnings and operating margin in the first quarter. I'd like to highlight the main reason for these
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you read in today's report, Reynolds American got off to an excellent start this year with sharply higher earnings and operating margin in the first quarter. I'd like to highlight the main reason for these strong results. First, is the continued strong performance by our operating companies and continued momentum in their powerful key brands. All of our reportable business segments, again, increased profit and operating margins, and they remain focused on strategic initiative to enhance their key brands in the competitive marketplace. 
Our company's results also benefited from higher pricing across the board and the end of the federal tobacco quote buyout late last year. 
In addition, cigarette volumes performed better than the historical decline rate. The decline in shipments continued to moderate, and we believe this was largely driven by improved economic factors, including lower gas prices as well as favorable comparison with the prior year quarter. 
One other development that favorably impacted our bottom line in the first quarter was the one-time benefit from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim. And Andrew will give you more details on that shortly. In addition, I would note R.J. Reynolds' announcement in February that the company, together with Philip Morris and Lorillard, has negotiated an agreement to resolve hundreds of Engle progeny lawsuits that are pending and not yet tried in the Florida federal court. This resolution was a unique opportunity to essentially close out of federal Engle progeny docket, although the agreement still has to be finalized. 
As part of our transforming tobacco strategy, our companies also make additional progress in positioning their innovative product platforms for long-term growth. As you know, RJR vapors
VUSE digital vapor cigarette completed its national expansion in the first quarter, and the brand is now available in about 100,000 outlets, namely convenience and gas stores. 
VUSE, a highly distinctive and superior vapor product continues to perform well, and the brand retained the #1 position in convenience gas outlets. VUSE added 4 more styles in Colorado and Utah late last year and as we expected, these are attracting the interest of adult smokers in vapors. 
Good progress is also being made with the national expansion of Nicotine's, Zonnic and Arteaga, and the brand will be in about 27,000 outlets, primarily convenience gas by the end of this month. 
In February, R.J. Reynolds expanded Revo heat-not-burn cigarettes in Wisconsin. Revo, which uses proprietary technology, is in nearly all contracted retail outlets in that state. Revo is getting strong support from point-of-sales signage and engagement with age-verified adult tobacco consumers as well as direct mail and e-mail for those adults who have registered to receive such information. 
Revo is still in very early days, and the focus remains on building brand awareness. So more to come on this as we get more data. 
So that's a quick update on our company's most recent achievements. I'd like to address one final item before we discuss our companies' performance in more detail. I know that you are all waiting for more news on our proposed acquisition of Lorillard. But all I can say at this point is that the regulatory approval process is still underway, and we remain confident that the transaction will close by the middle of this year. 
So now let's turn to the discussion of our quarterly results at our operating companies. R.J. Reynolds had a very strong quarter, with earnings and margin substantially higher on increased cigarette pricing and the favorable impact from the completion of the federal tobacco quota buyout. As I referenced earlier, the company's cigarette volume decline continued to moderate in the first quarter. 
R.J. Reynolds' total cigarette market share was down 5/10 [ph] of a percentage point from the prior year quarter at just over 26%. R.J. Reynolds' growth brands, Camel and Pall Mall, reflected solid market performance, and now make up about 3/4 of the company's total cigarette market share. Their combined first quarter share of 19.4% was in line with the prior year quarter. 
Camel's market share increased from the prior year quarter to 10.1%, and Camel continues to enhance its brand equity with the expansion of Camel White to 21 Western states in late March. This style, available in mellow and menthol, offers an in-set filter and premium tobacco that provides adult smokers with the perfect draw and smooth taste. 
Pall Mall, the nation's #1 value brand, continued to demonstrate solid performance in that category, and first quarter market share of 9.3% was down only slightly. Pall Mall is a longer-lasting, high-quality product at an affordable price, a true value proposition. And the focus remains on building awareness and trial. 
Now turning to American Snuff, which also generated strong financial performance in the first quarter. The moist snuff market continues to be highly competitive. The company increased its operating income by double-digits. And American Snuff's operating margin remains very strong. The company's overall moist snuff market share declined 2/10 [ph] of a percentage point to 34.5%. And the market share for its flagship Grizzly brand was in line with the prior year quarter at 31.6%. 
In late March, Grizzly expanded its Dark Wintergreen style nationally, a bold product offering that has a differentiated and richer flavor. Grizzly has led the growing Wintergreen segment since 2008, and Grizzly Dark Wintergreen is expected to continue the brand's momentum and further solidify its leadership position. 
I think it's fair to say that the star of the quarter was Santa Fe, where both financial and marketplace performance was outstanding. The company grew operating income by more than 40%. And that, of course, was driven by higher pricing and volume. Santa Fe's super-premium brand, Natural American Spirit, continues to go from strength to strength, and it increased first quarter market share by 3/10 [ph] of a percentage point to 1.8%. 
To put that in perspective, the NAS share increase was the biggest quarter-on-quarter increase in its history. And the brand shipped 1 billion cigarettes in the first quarter. 
Santa Fe is doing a really great job with Natural American Spirit, its expanding consumer franchise and the appeal of the brand's distinctive additive free tobacco style, including those made with organic tobacco continue to deliver impressive results. 
So that's a wrap of a very successful quarter, and I'm delighted with the progress our companies are making on all fronts. 
So now I'll turn the call over to Andrew, and welcome, Andrew, to your first earnings call.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI began the year in strong form. The quarter benefited from higher pricing in the completion of the federal tobacco quota buyout, and we increased adjusted EPS by almost 19.5% from the prior year quarter to
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI began the year in strong form. The quarter benefited from higher pricing in the completion of the federal tobacco quota buyout, and we increased adjusted EPS by almost 19.5% from the prior year quarter to $0.86. These adjusted results exclude a one-time benefit of $0.08 per share from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim. Pennsylvania and Missouri are no longer challenging the findings of non-diligence entered against them by the arbitration panel in connection with this claim. So part of the potential recovery from these 2 states is now certain and can be estimated. As a result, R.J. Reynolds' expenses for the MSA were reduce by $70 million for the first quarter. 
Our adjusted results also exclude a charge of $0.06 per share per transaction-related in financing cost in connection with the proposed Lorillard acquisition, $0.02 per share for tobacco-related and other litigation and the charge of $0.13 per share for Engle progeny lawsuits, including the proposed settlement for the federal cases. 
On a reported basis, first quarter EPS was $0.73, up 9% from the prior year quarter. RAI's adjusted operating margin continued to strengthen, coming in at 37.2% for the quarter. 
Now I'll turn to our operating companies performance, where I'll focus on the adjusted results. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results. 
R.J. Reynolds performed extremely well, with adjusted operating income increasing by more than 16% to $645 million. The company also increased adjusted operating margin by 4.6 percentage points to just over 40%. 
As Susan said, the company's cigarette volumes continued to moderate and were down 2.4% from the prior year quarter. Industry volume was up about 0.5%. Wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 6.5 billion units at the end of the first quarter, down to [ph] about 200 million from the prior year quarter. While R.J. Reynolds inventories of approximately 1.6 billion were down about 100 million. 
Now I'll turn to American Snuff.  Higher pricing and volume benefited first quarter operating income, which increased 16.7% to $118 million. The company's operating margin rose 3.8% to 58.9%. 
In addition to remaining very competitive, the moist snuff industry is clearly seeing an impact from the shift by adult tobacco consumers between various tobacco and vapor product. Industry volume was up just over 1% in the quarter, and American Snuff's volume increased 0.5%. 
As Susan said, Santa Fe continued to build on its strength and delivered outstanding results in the first quarter. The company increased operating income by nearly 42% to $92 million, and operating margin grew by 5.6 percentage points to almost 54%. These results were driven by the very strong performance of Natural American Spirit, which delivered volume growth of more than 23%. 
Now there are a couple of other items I want to mention before I open up the Q&A session. The company ended the quarter with cash balances of $1.6 billion, and I also want to confirm that R.J. Reynolds made its MSA payment of $1.4 billion in April, which included $429 million that was paid into the NPM disputed funds of Camel. 
Lastly, our outlook. As you can see from today's report, RAI and its operating companies had a great first quarter, and we are reaffirming our full year adjusted earnings guidance in the range of $3.65 to $3.80 per share. Please note that this guidance excludes any impact from our proposed transactions, and we will reassess our guidance after the proposed transactions close.  Thank you, all. 
Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Owen Bennett from Nomura.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Owen Bennett from Nomura.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, please. And firstly, and obviously a very strong quarter in terms of cigarette industry volumes. I was just wondering can you give any outlook for how you see industry volumes now trending through the rest of the year? And secondly,
componenttext: A couple of questions, please. And firstly, and obviously a very strong quarter in terms of cigarette industry volumes. I was just wondering can you give any outlook for how you see industry volumes now trending through the rest of the year? And secondly, you said previously you hoped for the Ebay provision at to become accretive by the second half. And does this still stand? It's just the loss in the first quarter seemed -- was a bit worse than what we had expected? Or is this just the case of the should the investment from below this year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Sure. Industry volumes were strong in the first quarter. If you think about that and look back to last year, when we saw what everybody was worried about was it was going away very quickly. And we talked about the inventory dollar being spen
componenttext: Thanks, Owen. Sure. Industry volumes were strong in the first quarter. If you think about that and look back to last year, when we saw what everybody was worried about was it was going away very quickly. And we talked about the inventory dollar being spent on vapor and vapor launches in the c-gas space, and that was taking away from inventory dollars in cigarettes. And I think that is proving to be true. So as the year unfolds, of course, this -- the volume will continue to be at this pace. We've always talked about a 3% to 4% decline sort of a long-term measure. Our guess is that this year, it will be on the low end of that. Call it 2 83[ph], 3 2 [ph] something like that. We'll continue to watch and see how that unfolds, but it was a very strong first quarter in volume terms. The other thing I would say about that in the context of the consumer, while there are technical inventory reasons, we also saw good premium mix in the first quarter with lower gas prices, and so we feel that, that has also impacted this -- the volume results. When we think about vapor, I think it's important to say that it's -- as you look at the dynamics of the segment at the moment, it looks like it's kind of flattened out. Now one of the reasons for that is we are lapping at again, huge numbers of launches. And of course, there's been a lot of consumer trial, and consumers are, perhaps, waiting for the next innovation, and we're still looking to get brand awareness and trial on VUSE. VUSE just went really achieve national distribution in the first quarter of this year, and so we certainly are spending to increase brand awareness in trial. As you know, we believe it's a superior vapor product that delivers real satisfaction. And therefore, we continue to invest in that trial. So certainly, as you said in the first quarter, it looks like we spent a fair amount of money, and we did because we're really driving for trial. And we would reiterate that in the medium term, we certainly expect to have very strong margins and profitability on VUSE. Whether that exactly occurs in the second half remains to be seen, because this is still a very volatile and dynamic category. Thanks, Owen.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Nik Modi from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Andrew, I was wondering if you can provide a little bit of context on legal cost. Now I'm just trying to get a sense of how much of your legal budget was being spent on Engle. That's number one. And second for Susan, if can you just give us some context around Santa Fe. I mean, is it level of volume growth should be expecting for the rest of the year? Or would this be pipeline still from new packaging that was kind of quarter-on-quarter. Any context around these 2 questions will be helpful.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nik. This is Andrew. Just a follow-up. A significant portion of our legal budget at this point is being spent on Engle. It is something that we obviously are looking at on a regular basis to see what does that affect of the proposed settlement on
componenttext: Thanks, Nik. This is Andrew. Just a follow-up. A significant portion of our legal budget at this point is being spent on Engle. It is something that we obviously are looking at on a regular basis to see what does that affect of the proposed settlement on the federal side. How does that play out for the rest of the year. But a significant portion, obviously, we've got a number of trials this year. We're expecting 30 to 45 trials, and that is obviously taking up a great portion of the legal budget.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nik, this is Susan. On Santa Fe, I think it really was the star of the quarter. When you look at that volume growth and that profitability growth, we continue to see the momentum we saw in the second half last year. If you -- Santa Fe, as we go through th
componenttext: Nik, this is Susan. On Santa Fe, I think it really was the star of the quarter. When you look at that volume growth and that profitability growth, we continue to see the momentum we saw in the second half last year. If you -- Santa Fe, as we go through this year, I think that the momentum will continue, but there are harder comparison in the second half than we have in the first half. Now having said that, the biggest market share jump we've ever seen on a quarter-over-quarter basis, 1 billion sticks in the quarter in which usually a relatively light quarter, we're very enthusiastic about that. And I think Santa Fe is benefiting, obviously, from us continuing to invest in the equity as well as the distribution of the brand and from the economics for the consumer in terms of the premium mix. So we are, obviously, very keen on Natural American Spirit, and we believe that it will continue to go from strength to strength.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Growe from Stifel.

componenttext: I just wanted a few questions first, if I could, and to follow up a bit on the industry volumes commentary before. I think is it after that inventories were down on the quarter. Just are we -- obviously, we have some momentum carryover from the second half of last year. Are we looking at industry volumes declining more like 3% instead of 4% like towards lower end of your range? Or have you given a better estimate what you expect for the year at this point?

componenttext: It certainly was down from the previous quarter end a year ago. So that's how we're looking at it, yes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Okay. I'm just curious, do think that price gap can expand a bit and just what that would mean for Camel versus Pall Mall in your portfolio?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you're right when you look at the economics of the category. We have seen that gap narrow, and we've seen consumer who is feeling good at the C gas store, shall we say. And how that exactly plays out, we've seen relatively stable pricing in the qu
componenttext: I think you're right when you look at the economics of the category. We have seen that gap narrow, and we've seen consumer who is feeling good at the C gas store, shall we say. And how that exactly plays out, we've seen relatively stable pricing in the quarter. We've seen good net price realization. Of course, as the year unfolds, eventually, we will lap the end of the quarter buyout, which is in the fourth quarter. But I think it remains to be seen. But it's still a highly competitive marketplace. And we are pleased with the results of both Pall Mall and Camel as well as, of course, Grizzly and NAS. But I think that the sector's in a good place, both with the consumer environment and with the volume, if you will.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Just one quick follow-up, which would be the market share for the brands you're divesting to Imperial, can you give that market share with those brands stand today? They're above that threshold, I assume?

componenttext: I would -- yes, they are above the threshold, and I don't think we need to go through the market shares specifically. But they are above the described threshold.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery from CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about Santa Fe in terms of some of the drivers? And I know you detailed some of the marketing and different things. But was there anything unusual in the quarter? And how much is international driving that? Is it -- is there an
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about Santa Fe in terms of some of the drivers? And I know you detailed some of the marketing and different things. But was there anything unusual in the quarter? And how much is international driving that? Is it -- is there any geographic expansion involved?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: We have, as we, I think, talked at Investor Day maybe at as well, we have added some sales force to Santa Fe. And I think that the brand is certainly benefiting from that. We also, of course, launched the updated packaging in the fourth quarter. And I think that is doing very well. And again, the general consumer environment is working well for premium. I think the equity of NAS, and it's absolutely spot on trend in terms of consumers looking for products, generally speaking, that have -- are additive-free and that -- and also, of course, we have some organic styles. But I think NAS in its superpremium format will continue to grow. Just for your information, there are no international numbers in that reported segment.

componenttext: Those are in other?

componenttext: Okay. Now that's helpful. And as far as the consumer environment being favorable, are you seeing greater trial? And what kind of repeat in adoption are you getting on that? componenttext: We can continue to see progress on NAS on a national basis. I think the soundbite was that it grew in 49 of 50 states or something. The distribution continues to get stronger with greater style availability and that we will continue to see that momentum.

componenttextpreview: We are pleased with the way it's performing internationally. I mean, as you know, this is a very small piece of our business. But certainly, from a brand proposition, the resonance and the response, we're very pleased.
componenttext: We are pleased with the way it's performing internationally. I mean, as you know, this is a very small piece of our business. But certainly, from a brand proposition, the resonance and the response, we're very pleased.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just one other one on the Revo. You've -- it's certainly very early there. What kind of things are you looking for as your guide to what would trigger a broader expansion there? And how is it looking like it's progressing against an
componenttext: That's great. And then just one other one on the Revo. You've -- it's certainly very early there. What kind of things are you looking for as your guide to what would trigger a broader expansion there? And how is it looking like it's progressing against any of those benchmarks?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as I've said in the prepared remark, you're absolutely right, it is very early days. And we talked about this. Also, I think at our investor presentation where this proprietary heat-not-burn technology and the consumers' understanding of tha
componenttext: Well, I think as I've said in the prepared remark, you're absolutely right, it is very early days. And we talked about this. Also, I think at our investor presentation where this proprietary heat-not-burn technology and the consumers' understanding of that, seeing it between vapor and combustibles is very important. And so what we're really looking at is proposition understanding. And if people understands a proposition and they try, do they convert? And so the -- it's going to take some time to get that data. So we are pleased so far that the brand awareness is building and that then the trial will build. And then, of course, the trigger, as always, is do they convert is and is there enough repeat purchase to justify a business expansion? So we will continue to watch that. But we're certainly encouraged with the distribution penetration as I mentioned, and we will keep you posted.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when you say awareness, are you measuring an understanding of the proposition? Or is it more just that they've seen a point -- that they've heard of the brand? How deep is that awareness measure and obviously, it's not a super exact science. But are y
componenttext: And when you say awareness, are you measuring an understanding of the proposition? Or is it more just that they've seen a point -- that they've heard of the brand? How deep is that awareness measure and obviously, it's not a super exact science. But are you trying to get it? When you say awareness, does that get it from an understanding of what the proposition is?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It really has to and particularly, in a unique product, such as Revo because being aware of it, but the understanding what kind of -- what this heat-not-burn mean and how -- what are their expectations in terms of how the product will perform, you've
componenttext: Yes. It really has to and particularly, in a unique product, such as Revo because being aware of it, but the understanding what kind of -- what this heat-not-burn mean and how -- what are their expectations in terms of how the product will perform, you've got to have proposition awareness to be able to convert people from trial to conversion and loyalty. So yes, we -- it is a deeper measure. And as I said, as this -- as we get more clarity, we'll certainly share that with you.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe a question about the moist tobacco category. Just in terms of the positive economic impact that we're seeing from a consumer perspective on the cigarettes. Obviously, that doesn't seem to be impacting the smokeless tobacco category. So is there,
componenttext: So maybe a question about the moist tobacco category. Just in terms of the positive economic impact that we're seeing from a consumer perspective on the cigarettes. Obviously, that doesn't seem to be impacting the smokeless tobacco category. So is there, number one, an element the smokeless tobacco consumers that may have traded or cigarette consumers that may have traded down to smokeless in a more difficult economic environment than they're trading up to the cigarette category? Where are you seeing more of the volume from smokeless tobacco going as you think about the broader tobacco categories?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Judy, and I think you're spot on. Remember that there are 9 million smokeless users and 5 million of those are dual users. And so I think there are several factors impacting this moist category. One, certainly, is your hypothesis that as the consu
componenttext: Thanks, Judy, and I think you're spot on. Remember that there are 9 million smokeless users and 5 million of those are dual users. And so I think there are several factors impacting this moist category. One, certainly, is your hypothesis that as the consumers are feeling better and they have a choice between cigarettes and moist, and they want to have a cigarette. That is happening. Second of all, of course, moist users seem to be the most promiscuous, if you will, across the new alternatives. So we see a lot of trial in vapor amongst moist users. We've always seen the trial of SNUS, a lot of that came from our moist users. And so they are more experimental. And so correspondingly, we see, I think it was 1% or so growth in that moist category in the first quarter. We're very pleased with Grizzly's performance, strong financial performance in a very competitive environment. This year year-over-year relatively flat, but we continue to lead the wintergreen category and our pouch, which is also the -- one of the fastest-growing category is also the fastest growing. So I think we'll see where those moist users land over time, but we're very pleased with the Grizzly's participation.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then Andrew, just a couple of, I guess, the P&L questions. First, on the NPM adjustment claims. I just want to understand, I guess, make sure that I understand correctly. headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Grainger for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions, and some of these you may not be able to address, but just what we can add. First, so you're generating very strong operating profit growth at RJR at the moment. And obviously, the stronger volumes on your growth brands. But pr
componenttext: Just a couple of questions, and some of these you may not be able to address, but just what we can add. First, so you're generating very strong operating profit growth at RJR at the moment. And obviously, the stronger volumes on your growth brands. But presumably, the high levels of pricing realization are spread across the portfolio. And you may not be able to decompose this, but is this the case where the profit growth is disproportionately skewed to the growth brands? Or is it more evenly spread across the RJR portfolio? And if so, does that result in a slightly higher contribution margin for the divested brands once the transaction closes?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think -- I'm not going to dissect the profit growth across the brand portfolio. We're very pleased with the profit growth. We have a 40% margin at RJRT, and we are confident in the way that this is balanced. So that's it.
componenttext: Matt, I think -- I'm not going to dissect the profit growth across the brand portfolio. We're very pleased with the profit growth. We have a 40% margin at RJRT, and we are confident in the way that this is balanced. So that's it.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more just about the Engle settlement on the federal cases. And what you see is the benefits of that. I definitely understand the arguments in favor of foreclosing the tail risk associated with those and the favorabili
componenttext: Okay. And could you talk a little bit more just about the Engle settlement on the federal cases. And what you see is the benefits of that. I definitely understand the arguments in favor of foreclosing the tail risk associated with those and the favorability on legal expenses. But do you think there's an inherent risk to settling in such a high-profile classification?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think as we've said in our releases, we feel that putting behind us these hundreds of cases on the federal docket is the best result. And while the settlement isn't finalized, it makes sense for us from a legal expense perspective. And we don't be
componenttext: Matt, I think as we've said in our releases, we feel that putting behind us these hundreds of cases on the federal docket is the best result. And while the settlement isn't finalized, it makes sense for us from a legal expense perspective. And we don't believe it will have negative impact on our ability to try the state cases. So we have done a lot of evaluation of this settlement and believe it's the best way forward.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just on guidance and the competitive environment. I know probably on some level, there's a desire to wait until the potential closure of the transaction to revisit guidance. But in prior quarters, you've talked about your guidance r
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just on guidance and the competitive environment. I know probably on some level, there's a desire to wait until the potential closure of the transaction to revisit guidance. But in prior quarters, you've talked about your guidance range accounting for some degree of competitive uncertainty going forward. I guess, my question is after several quarters a very strong pricing, that doesn't seem to have slowed that materially. You think the level of competitive uncertainty in the cigarette category has declined? Or has it taken a step back in a way that might persist for the foreseeable future?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the competitiveness of the category is very strong, and everybody is executing against their strategy. As it relates to our guidance, of course, we will look at revising our guidance upon the closure of the transaction. So -- and traditionall
componenttext: I think that the competitiveness of the category is very strong, and everybody is executing against their strategy. As it relates to our guidance, of course, we will look at revising our guidance upon the closure of the transaction. So -- and traditionally, we have looked at our guidance as the years unfolded and tightened that range. And we would certainly expect to do that if for some reason that the transaction doesn't conclude. But as I said, we remain confident.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bonnie Herzog from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bonnie Herzog from Wells Fargo.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on your margin but just asking a little bit differently. Your expansion of 4.6% was huge. So could you drill down on the drivers behind this to help us understand how much of this is driven from higher pricing and favorable mix shift
componenttext: My first question is on your margin but just asking a little bit differently. Your expansion of 4.6% was huge. So could you drill down on the drivers behind this to help us understand how much of this is driven from higher pricing and favorable mix shift versus your lower cost. And then could you also quantify your net price realization? I'm not sure if you did that yet.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bonnie. I think -- this is Andrew. I think as we look at this, obviously, net price realization was a key driver of this. We did see some growth of 5.9% at RJRT net price realization. The other driver, obviously, on the cost side that you're seeing i
componenttext: Yes, Bonnie. I think -- this is Andrew. I think as we look at this, obviously, net price realization was a key driver of this. We did see some growth of 5.9% at RJRT net price realization. The other driver, obviously, on the cost side that you're seeing is the tobacco core the buyout ending last September. So that obviously played a significant role in the cost coming down as well. And it's really those 2 drivers that are -- along with the volume that are driving this.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then a question on Camel. Susan, you mentioned the lower gas prices are certainly helping and I'm also hearing is from a lot of the retailers, which is leading to up trading. So was this one of the key drivers behind your Camel's strong performance? A
componenttext: And then a question on Camel. Susan, you mentioned the lower gas prices are certainly helping and I'm also hearing is from a lot of the retailers, which is leading to up trading. So was this one of the key drivers behind your Camel's strong performance? And then you believe you can retain Camel's strong volume momentum once gas prices go back up?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Camel as we continue to invest in new styles like Camel White and in the equity behind the brand that Camel's momentum, which we've really seen over the last several years and the momentum of capsule that, obviously, if people are trading up
componenttext: Well, I think Camel as we continue to invest in new styles like Camel White and in the equity behind the brand that Camel's momentum, which we've really seen over the last several years and the momentum of capsule that, obviously, if people are trading up and they are satisfied and become loyal to the brand that we would be able to continue that. And of course, gas prices is a very real economic change for our consumers. But the general economy also has an impact. So if gas prices go up, but the general economy also rises and it affects wages, then that keeps our consumer in a good place. So we'll continue to watch this, but of course, it was a very favorable quarter.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And then as just my final question is on vapor. Although the broad vapor market is still growing quite a bit, the growth seems to have moderated. And a couple of concerns I have include when the performance of existing products in the market s
componenttext: Absolutely. And then as just my final question is on vapor. Although the broad vapor market is still growing quite a bit, the growth seems to have moderated. And a couple of concerns I have include when the performance of existing products in the market still is a strong enough for greater conversion from combustible cigs. And then secondly, there's an increasing perception that e-cigs and vapor may not be as safe as originally assumed. So I was hoping to hear your thoughts on both of these topics and what your strategy is to address them.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I said, I think we've also seen, and I think your report on that was absolutely right that we're seeing flattening in the space. Of course, there's continued growth of the tanks and the mods and the liquids and how does that affect the e-cig-alike
componenttext: Yes. As I said, I think we've also seen, and I think your report on that was absolutely right that we're seeing flattening in the space. Of course, there's continued growth of the tanks and the mods and the liquids and how does that affect the e-cig-alike market and it's still very, very dynamic. What we do know is there's been tremendous trial vapor across cigarette smokers. And the conversion has not been as high as we would have liked to see. And yet there is continued use. And so what that would say to us is that people aren't finding the complete satisfaction either from a convenience or from a satisfaction perspective in the vapor space as of today. Now we still believe there's a lot of upside for VUSE because we do know when we get that into the hands of cigarette smokers or people who have already moved to vaping that it is satisfying. So I think we would expect to see is there will be more trial, and we will continue to drive trial on VUSE specifically. But then are consumers who are waiting for something that isn't out there yet. And they're looking for perhaps satisfaction and convenience that's not available as they know it today. So I think that also there is an impact of your second point, which is the contradictory information in the media about the relative less harm of e-cigarettes. And I believe the conversion to e-cigarettes has the potential to be good for public health, and I believe that's still what the data imply. But there is a lot of contradictory arguments. And this is making consumers question whether or not they should be in the vapor category. So I think that it is very important that we continue to see public entities and lawmakers provide consumers with accurate information on the potential for harm reduction across the continuum. And we would -- we continue to be proponents of that. So I think we're just in the timeframe when everything is scrambling, but hopefully, there will be more clarity and there will be more science and more people who have the capacity and the credibility to talk about that science.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Reynolds American First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. Now I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Morris Moore, Vic
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Reynolds American First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
Now I would like to hand the conference over to Mr. Morris Moore, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the first quarter and our outlook for the full year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management believes this provides better p
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the first quarter and our outlook for the full year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management believes this provides better perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release, which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com. Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO.
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you read in today's report, Reynolds American got off to an excellent start this year, with sharply higher earnings and operating margin in the first quarter. I'd like to highlight the main reason for thes
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you read in today's report, Reynolds American got off to an excellent start this year, with sharply higher earnings and operating margin in the first quarter. I'd like to highlight the main reason for these strong results. First is the continued strong performance by our operating companies and continued momentum in their powerful key brands. All of our reportable business segments, again, increased profit and operating margins, and they remain focused on strategic initiative to enhance their key brands in the competitive marketplace. 
Our company's results also benefited from higher pricing across the board and the end of the federal tobacco quote buyout late last year. In addition, cigarette volumes performed better than the historical decline rate. The decline in shipments continued to moderate, and we believe this was largely driven by improved economic factors, including lower gas prices as well as favorable comparison with the prior year quarter. 
One other development that favorably impacted our bottom line in the first quarter was the onetime benefit from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim. And Andrew will give you more details on that shortly. In addition, I would note R.J. Reynolds' announcement in February that the company, together with Philip Morris and Lorillard, has negotiated an agreement to resolve hundreds of Engle progeny lawsuits that are pending and not yet tried in the Florida federal court. This resolution was a unique opportunity to essentially close out the federal Engle progeny docket, although the agreement still has to be finalized. 
As part of our transforming tobacco strategy, our company's also made additional progress in positioning their innovative product platform for long-term growth. As you know, RJR 
VUSE digital vapor cigarette completed its national expansion in the first quarter, and the brand is now available in about 100,000 outlets, mainly convenience and gas stores. 
VUSE, a highly distinctive and superior vapor product, continues to perform well, and the brand retained the #1 position in convenience gas outlets. VUSE added 4 more styles in Colorado and Utah late last year and, as we expected, these are attracting the interest of adult smokers in vapors. Good progress is also being made with the national expansion of Niconovum's Zonnic NRT gum, and the brand will be in about 27,000 outlets, primarily convenience gas, by the end of this month. 
In February, R.J. Reynolds expanded Revo heat-not-burn cigarettes in Wisconsin. Revo, which uses proprietary technology, is in nearly all contracted retail outlets in that state. Revo is getting strong support from point-of-sales signage and engagement with age-verified adult tobacco consumers as well as direct mail and e-mail for those adults who have registered to receive such information 
Revo is still in very early days, and the focus remains on building brand awareness. So more to come on this as we get more data. 
So that's a quick update on our company's most recent achievements. I'd like to address one final item before we discuss our companies' performance in more detail. I know that you are all waiting for more news on our proposed acquisition of Lorillard. But all I can say at this point is that the regulatory approval process is still underway, and we remain confident that the transaction will close by the middle of this year. 
So now let's turn to the discussion of our quarterly results at our operating companies. R.J. Reynolds had a very strong quarter, with earnings and margin substantially higher on increased cigarette pricing and the favorable impact from the completion of the federal tobacco-quota buyout. As I referenced earlier, the company's cigarette volume decline continued to moderate in the first quarter. 
R.J. Reynolds' total cigarette market share was down 0.5 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter at just over 26%. R.J. Reynolds' growth brands, Camel and Pall Mall, reflected solid market performance, and now make up about 3/4 of the company's total cigarette market share. Their combined first quarter share of 19.4% was in line with the prior year quarter. 
Camel's market share increased from the prior year quarter to 10.1%, and Camel continues to enhance its brand equity with the expansion of Camel White to 21 Western states in late March. This style, available in mellow and menthol, offers an inset filter and premium tobacco that provides adult smokers with the perfect draw and smooth taste. 
Pall Mall, the nation's #1 value brand, continue to demonstrate solid performance in that category, and first quarter market share of 9.3% was down only slightly. Pall Mall is a longer-lasting, high-quality product at an affordable price, a true value proposition. And the focus remains on building awareness and trial. 
Now turning to American Snuff, which also generated strong financial performance in the first quarter. The moist snuff market continues to be highly competitive, but the company increased its operating income by double-digits. And American Snuff's operating margin remains very strong. The company's overall moist snuff market share declined 0.2 of a percentage point to 34.5%. And the market share for its flagship Grizzly brand was in line with the prior year quarter at 31.6%. 
In late March, Grizzly expanded its Dark Wintergreen style nationally, a bold product offering that has a differentiated and richer flavor. Grizzly has led the growing Wintergreen segment since 2008, and Grizzly Dark Wintergreen is expected to continue the brand's momentum and further solidify its leadership position. 
I think it's fair to say that the star of the quarter was Santa Fe, where both financial and marketplace performance was outstanding. The company grew operating income by more than 40%. And that, of course, was driven by higher pricing and volume. Santa Fe's super-premium brand, Natural American Spirit, continues to go from strength to strength, and it increased first quarter market share by 0.3 of a percentage point to 1.8%. 
To put that in perspective, the NAS share increase was the biggest quarter-on-quarter increase in its history. And the brand shipped 1 billion cigarettes in the first quarter. 
Santa Fe is doing a really great job with Natural American Spirit, its expanding consumer franchise and the appeal of the brand's distinctive additive-free tobacco style, including those made with organic tobacco, continue to deliver impressive results. 
So that's a wrap of a very successful quarter, and I'm delighted with the progress our companies are making on all fronts. So now I'll turn the call over to Andrew, and welcome, Andrew, to your first earnings call.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI began the year in strong form. The quarter benefited from higher pricing and the completion of the federal tobacco-quota buyout, and we increased adjusted EPS by almost 19.5% from the prior year quarter to
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI began the year in strong form. The quarter benefited from higher pricing and the completion of the federal tobacco-quota buyout, and we increased adjusted EPS by almost 19.5% from the prior year quarter to $0.86. These adjusted results exclude a one-time benefit of $0.08 per share from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim. Pennsylvania and Missouri are no longer challenging the findings of non-diligence entered against them by the arbitration panel in connection with this claim. So part of the potential recovery from these 2 states is now certain and can be estimated. As a result, R.J. Reynolds' expenses for the MSA were reduce by $70 million for the first quarter. 
Our adjusted results also exclude a charge of $0.06 per share per transaction-related in financing cost in connection with the proposed Lorillard acquisition, $0.02 per share for tobacco-related and other litigations and the charge of $0.13 per share for Engle progeny lawsuits, including the proposed settlement for the federal cases. 
On a reported basis, first quarter EPS was $0.73, up 9% from the prior year quarter. RAI's adjusted operating margin continued to strengthen, coming in at 37.2% for the quarter. 
Now I'll turn to our operating companies' performance, where I'll focus on the adjusted results. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results. R.J. Reynolds performed extremely well, with adjusted operating income increasing by more than 16% to $645 million. The company also increased adjusted operating margin by 4.6 percentage points to just over 40%. 
As Susan said, the company's cigarette volumes continued to moderate and were down 2.4% from the prior year quarter. Industry volume was up about 0.5%. Wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 6.5 billion units at the end of the first quarter, down to about 200 million from the prior year quarter. While R.J. Reynolds' inventories of approximately 1.6 billion were down about 100 million. 
Now I'll turn to American Snuff.  Higher pricing and volume benefited first quarter operating income, which increased 16.7% to $118 million. The company's operating margin rose 3.8% to 58.9%. In addition to remaining very competitive, the moist snuff industry is clearly seeing an impact from the shift by adult tobacco consumers between various tobacco and vapor product. Industry volume was up just over 1% in the quarter, and American Snuff's volume increased 0.5%. 
As Susan said, Santa Fe continued to build on its strength and delivered outstanding results in the first quarter. The company increased operating income by nearly 42% to $92 million, and operating margin grew by 5.6 percentage points to almost 54%. These results were driven by the very strong performance of Natural American Spirit, which delivered volume growth of more than 23%. 
Now there are a couple of other items I want to mention before I open up the Q&A session. The company ended the quarter with cash balances of $1.6 billion, and I also want to confirm that R.J. Reynolds made its MSA payment of $1.4 billion in April, which included $429 million that was paid into the NPM disputed funds account. 
Lastly, our outlook. As you can see from today's report, RAI and its operating companies had a great first quarter, and we are reaffirming our full year adjusted earnings guidance in the range of $3.65 to $3.80 per share. Please note that this guidance excludes any impact from our proposed transactions, and we will reassess our guidance after the proposed transactions close.  Thank you, all. 
Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Owen Bennett from Nomura.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Owen Bennett from Nomura.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, please. Firstly -- and obviously a very strong quarter in terms of cigarette industry volumes. I was just wondering can you give any outlook for how you see industry volumes now trending through the rest of the year? Secondly, you s
componenttext: A couple of questions, please. Firstly -- and obviously a very strong quarter in terms of cigarette industry volumes. I was just wondering can you give any outlook for how you see industry volumes now trending through the rest of the year? Secondly, you said previously you hoped for the eBay provision to become accretive by the second half. And does this still stand? It's just the loss in the first quarter seemed is was a bit worse than what we had expected? Or is this just the case of should the investment would trend below this year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. Sure. Industry volumes were strong in the first quarter. If you think about that and look back to last year when we saw, what everybody was worried about, was it was going away very quickly. And we talked about the inventory dollar being spe
componenttext: Thanks, Owen. Sure. Industry volumes were strong in the first quarter. If you think about that and look back to last year when we saw, what everybody was worried about, was it was going away very quickly. And we talked about the inventory dollar being spent on vapor and vapor launches in the C-GAS space and that, that was taking away from inventory dollars in cigarettes. And I think that is proving to be true. So as the year unfolds, of course, this -- the volume will continue to be at this pace. We've always talked about a 3% to 4% decline in sort of a long-term measure. Our guess is that this year it will be on the low end of that, call it 2.8%, 3%, 3.2%, something like that. We'll continue to watch and see how that unfolds. But it was a very strong first quarter in volume terms. The other thing I would say about that in the context of the consumer, while there are technical inventory reasons, we also saw good premium mix in the first quarter with lower gas prices, and so we feel that, that has also impacted this -- the volume results. When we think about vapor, I think it's important to say that it's -- as you look at the dynamics of the segment at the moment, it looks like it's kind of flattened out. Now one of the reason for that is we are lapping at, again, huge numbers of launches. And of course, there's been a lot of consumer trial, and consumers are, perhaps, waiting for the next innovation. And we're still looking to get brand awareness and trial on VUSE. VUSE just went really -- achieve national distribution in the first quarter of this year, and so we certainly are spending to increase brand awareness in trial. As you know, we believe it's a superior vapor product that delivers real satisfaction. And therefore, we continue to invest in that trial. So certainly, as you said in the first quarter, it looks like we spent a fair amount of money, and we did because we're really driving for trial. And we would reiterate that in the medium term, we certainly expect to have very strong margins and profitability on VUSE. Whether that exactly occurs in the second half remains to be seen, because this is still a very volatile and dynamic category. Thanks, Owen.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nik Modi from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nik Modi from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I was wondering if you can provide a little bit of context on legal cost, just trying to get a sense of how much of your legal budget was being spent on Engle. That's number one. And then second, for Susan, if can you just give us some context aro
componenttext: Andrew, I was wondering if you can provide a little bit of context on legal cost, just trying to get a sense of how much of your legal budget was being spent on Engle. That's number one. And then second, for Susan, if can you just give us some context around Santa Fe. I mean, is this level of volume growth something we should be expecting for the rest of the year? Or would this be pipeline sale from new packaging that was kind of quarter-on-quarter. Any context around these 2 questions will be helpful.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Nik. This is Andrew. Just a follow-up. A significant portion of our legal budget at this point is being spent on Engle. It is something that we obviously are looking at on a regular basis to see what does that affect of the proposed settlemen
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Nik. This is Andrew. Just a follow-up. A significant portion of our legal budget at this point is being spent on Engle. It is something that we obviously are looking at on a regular basis to see what does that affect of the proposed settlement on the federal side. How does that play out for the rest of the year. But a significant portion, obviously, we've got a number of trials this year. We're expecting 30 to 45 trials, and that is obviously taking up a great portion of the legal budget.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nik, this is Susan. On Santa Fe, I think it really was the star of the quarter. When you look at that volume growth and that profitability growth, we continue to see the momentum we saw in the second half last year. If you -- Santa Fe, as we go through th
componenttext: Nik, this is Susan. On Santa Fe, I think it really was the star of the quarter. When you look at that volume growth and that profitability growth, we continue to see the momentum we saw in the second half last year. If you -- Santa Fe, as we go through this year, I think that the momentum will continue, but there are harder comparison in the second half than we have in the first half. Now having said that, the biggest market share jump we've ever seen on a quarter-over-quarter basis, 1 billion sticks in the quarter and what's usually a relatively light quarter, we're very enthusiastic about that. And I think Santa Fe is benefiting, obviously, from us continuing to invest in the equity as well as the distribution of the brand and from the economics for the consumer in terms of the premium mix. So we are, obviously, very keen on Natural American Spirit, and we believe that it will continue to go from strength to strength.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Growe from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Growe from Stifel.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted a few questions first, if I could, and to follow up a bit on the industry volumes commentary before. I think you said in the intro that inventories were down in the quarter. I think you also mentioned at one point that this -- there was a --
componenttext: I just wanted a few questions first, if I could, and to follow up a bit on the industry volumes commentary before. I think you said in the intro that inventories were down in the quarter. I think you also mentioned at one point that this -- there was a -- this is a bit of an easier comp than the first quarter. So I'm not sure if you gave a number, Susan, if you did, I missed it. Just are we -- obviously, we have some momentum carryover from the second half of last year. Are we looking at industry volumes declining more like 3% instead of 4%, like towards lower end of your range? Or have you given a better estimate of what you expect for the year at this point?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Yes, I did say that. I did say that we believe that they will be at the lower end of that range, of that 3% to 4% range. So call it 3%.
componenttext: Thanks, Chris. Yes, I did say that. I did say that we believe that they will be at the lower end of that range, of that 3% to 4% range. So call it 3%.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: And was there any -- there was an inventory adjustment it seems like in the quarter for the category overall for the industry and it was down year-over-year, is that right?
componenttext: And was there any -- there was an inventory adjustment it seems like in the quarter for the category overall for the industry and it was down year-over-year, is that right?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: It certainly was down from the previous quarter end a year ago. So that's basically how we're looking at it, yes.
componenttext: It certainly was down from the previous quarter end a year ago. So that's basically how we're looking at it, yes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. Just one other question, if I could, on the cigarette business, just the price gap between premium and discount brands has narrowed and economic conditions are in better shape and gas prices are lower and that kind of thing. I'm just curiou
componenttext: Got you. Okay. Just one other question, if I could, on the cigarette business, just the price gap between premium and discount brands has narrowed and economic conditions are in better shape and gas prices are lower and that kind of thing. I'm just curious, do think that price gap can expand a bit, and just what that would mean for Camel versus Pall Mall in your portfolio?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you're right. When you look at the economics of the category, we have seen that gap narrow, and we've seen a consumer who is feeling good at the C-GAS store, shall we say. And how that exactly plays out, we've seen relatively stable pricing in the
componenttext: I think you're right. When you look at the economics of the category, we have seen that gap narrow, and we've seen a consumer who is feeling good at the C-GAS store, shall we say. And how that exactly plays out, we've seen relatively stable pricing in the quarter. We've seen good net price realization. Of course, as the year unfolds, eventually, we will lap the end of the quarter buyout, which is in the fourth quarter. But I think it remains to be seen, but it's still a highly competitive marketplace. And we are pleased with the results of both Pall Mall and Camel as well as, of course, Grizzly and NAS. But I think that the sector's in a good place, both with the consumer environment and with the volume, if you will.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up, which would be the market share for the brands you're divesting to Imperial, can you give that market share with those brands stand today? They're above the threshold, I assume?
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up, which would be the market share for the brands you're divesting to Imperial, can you give that market share with those brands stand today? They're above the threshold, I assume?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would -- yes, they are above the threshold, and I don't think we need to go through the market shares specifically. But they are above the described threshold.
componenttext: I would -- yes, they are above the threshold, and I don't think we need to go through the market shares specifically. But they are above the described threshold.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery from CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about Santa Fe in terms of some of the drivers? And I know you detailed some of the marketing and different things. But was there anything unusual in the quarter? And how much is international driving that? Is it -- is there an
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about Santa Fe in terms of some of the drivers? And I know you detailed some of the marketing and different things. But was there anything unusual in the quarter? And how much is international driving that? Is it -- is there any geographic expansion involved?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have, as we I think talked at Investor Day, maybe at CAGNY as well, we have added some sales force to Santa Fe. And I think that the brand is certainly benefiting from that. We also, of course, launched the updated packaging in the fourth quarter. And
componenttext: We have, as we I think talked at Investor Day, maybe at CAGNY as well, we have added some sales force to Santa Fe. And I think that the brand is certainly benefiting from that. We also, of course, launched the updated packaging in the fourth quarter. And I think that is doing very well. And again, the general consumer environment is working well for premium. I think the equity of NAS, and it's absolutely spot on trend in terms of consumers looking for products, generally speaking, that have -- are additive-free and that -- and also, of course, we have some organic styles. But I think NAS, in its super premium format, will continue to grow. Just for your information, there are no international numbers in that reported segment.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Those are in other?
componenttext: Those are in other?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's helpful. And as far as the consumer environment being favorable, are you seeing greater trial? And what kind of repeat in adoption are you getting on that? Is this a deeper penetration? And how much of that were -- you're concentrated, ce
componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful. And as far as the consumer environment being favorable, are you seeing greater trial? And what kind of repeat in adoption are you getting on that? Is this a deeper penetration? And how much of that were -- you're concentrated, certainly, in very high shares in some cities, how much of that is spreading into newer areas where it's typically not being as well developed?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 17, 2015
