headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Reynolds American Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I'd like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Morris Moor
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Reynolds American Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I'd like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Morris Moore, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the second quarter and first half and our revised outlook for the rest of the year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the second quarter and first half and our revised outlook for the rest of the year. As usual, our discussion will focus on adjusted results as management believes this provides better perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release, which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com. Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO. The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by Federal Securities Laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As our report today makes clear, we accomplished a great deal during the second quarter, making further progress in our continuing transformation journey. In mid-June, of course, we successfully completed RAI
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As our report today makes clear, we accomplished a great deal during the second quarter, making further progress in our continuing transformation journey. In mid-June, of course, we successfully completed RAI's purchase of Lorillard and the related divestiture to ITG Brands. And I'm pleased to say that the integration of the Newport brand is going very well. Our employees have done a fantastic job in managing the initial transition. In fact, RAI had an excellent quarter, reporting substantially higher earnings and operating margin, and that wrapped up a very successful first half. These results reflected strong financial performance at all of our operating companies and continued momentum behind their distinctive brands. Of course, I would note that given the timing of the closing in mid-June, second quarter results versus last year are not directly comparable. 
So it was a strong second quarter in first half, marked by higher pricing across the board and strong volumes. And now we're poised for new growth following the acquisition. As we said all along, the addition of the Newport brand will give R.J. Reynolds increased scale and improved operational efficiencies, as well as higher sales volumes, resulting from the complementary nature of Newport and the rest of R.J. Reynolds's cigarette portfolio. The result will be a significantly more profitable business that will continue to reward shareholders and fuel the continued research development and innovation that our companies need for long-term sustainability in a changing environment. 
Our transition is still far from complete and here, I would remind you that the manufacturing of Newport will continue under a reciprocal agreement until production is fully transferred to the Tobaccoville manufacturing facility later next year. 
A good deal of work remains to be done, but we have a great track record in executing these kinds of combinations and I'm confident that the process will continue to run smoothly. The second quarter's strong business performance has reinforced our confidence in the continuing strength of our operating companies, so we're making several important announcements this morning. We are increasing our quarterly cash dividend by 7.5%. This is our 12th dividend increase since RAI was formed in 2004. We're also implementing a 2-for-1 stock split, which will be our third stock split since 2004. 
In addition, we have increased our adjusted earnings growth projection for the year to a range of 11% to 17% over last year's adjusted results. That compares with our previous 2015 guidance of 6.7% to 11% growth. I think you'll agree that these actions clearly demonstrate a high level of conviction for our businesses as well as our commitment to returning value to our shareholders. And Andrew will be giving you some more details shortly. 
Before I move on to discuss our operating performance, I'd like to give you a quick update on our progress with other key aspects of our transforming tobacco strategy. I'm pleased to report that RJR Vapor's VUSE digital vapor cigarette continued to perform well in the second quarter. VUSE, which uses digital technology to deliver a superior vaping experience, has been a consistent category leader. VUSE is now in national distribution in more than 100,000 retail outlets and has solidified its position as the top-selling electronic cigarette in the C-store channel. VUSE's success is based not just on its strong and distinctive product qualities, the brand also offers retailers best-in-class support, with high-impact national and local marketing campaign. We continue to see great promise in the vapor category, and we will continue to innovate and invest to keep VUSE as the leading, most advanced product in the marketplace. 
Good progress also continues to be made with the national expansion of Niconovum, Zonnic, NRT Gum, and the brand is now in about 25,000 outlets. Zonnic is the leading NRT in the convenience gas channel, and we expect its phased expansion to continue into next year. Also, as you know, R.J. Reynolds expanded Revo, heat-not-burn cigarette, into Wisconsin in February, to gain learning on consumer interest in heat-not-burn products. Revo has seen consumer interest and trial but actual adoption rates of the product have not met our expectations. As a result, R.J. Reynolds has decided to discontinue marketing support for Revo in Wisconsin. However, we do remain optimistic about the long-term potential for heat-not-burn, and we continue to work to improve this technology. 
So that's a quick review of the quarter's main headlines. Before I turn to discussion of the results at our operating companies, I would just note here that we have refreshed our corporate branding and redesigned our website to reflect the new brand portfolio, and there'll be more news on that in early August. 
I'd also note that we've changed the method of measuring our operating companies, cigarettes and moist snuff retail market share, to more accurately reflect marketplace performance across all channels. While absolute retail market share levels may differ from previously reported data, the overall trends are not materially different. 
Now let's start the discussion with traditional cigarettes, which we refer to as combustible. Total RAI operating companies’ domestic cigarette volumes increased 5.6% in the second quarter and 2.4% for the first 6 months of 2015. This compares to cigarette industry gains of 1.9% and 1.2% during the same periods. However, on an inventory adjusted basis, industry cigarette volumes were down slightly for both periods. Total RAI operating companies domestic retail market share increased 0.2 percentage points to 33.6% in the second quarter and 0.1 percentage point to 33.8% for the first half of 2015. 
R.J. Reynolds turned in another strong quarter, supported by higher cigarette pricing and the completion of the federal tobacco-quota buyout. In addition, the company's cigarette shipments increased in the second quarter, benefiting from the addition of 2 weeks of Newport. R.J. Reynolds's cigarette volumes therefore increased by almost 4.5%. I also need to note that R.J. Reynolds's retail market share is presented on a pro forma basis, which reflects share information from the company's new brand portfolio, following the Lorillard acquisition and the related divestiture. As a result, R.J. Reynolds's total cigarette retail market share was down slightly from the prior year quarter at 31.8%. 
R.J. Reynolds's new portfolio of growth brands, Newport, Camel and Pall Mall, performed well in the second quarter, and now make up more than 90% of the company's total cigarette market share. Their combined second quarter share was 29.2%, and that was up 0.2 percentage point from the prior year quarter. 
Newport continued to advance in the second quarter, with share of retail shipments increasing 0.4 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 13.2%. Newport's gains were driven by its strength in menthol, and R.J. Reynolds's strategy going forward will be to energize and reinforce this powerful brand. 
Camel also continued to benefit from its menthol styles that use capsule technology. And the brand's total cigarette retail market share was in line with the prior year quarter at 8.2%. 
R.J. Reynolds's Pall Mall value brand is playing an essential role in the company's portfolio strategy by providing the right balance between market share and profitability. As a result, Pall Mall's second quarter retail market share of 7.8% was down 0.3 percentage points from the prior year quarter. This true value proposition is expected to benefit from additional brand equity building efforts going forward, resulting in increased trial and conversion. 
At Santa Fe, performance continues to exceed even our own high expectation. The company increased second quarter operating income by almost 50% and reported a significant quarterly jump in operating margin. The Santa Fe team is really executing wonderfully, and of course, the Natural American Spirit brand is the driving force. This undiscounted super-premium brand ended the quarter with a retail market share of 1.8% on volume growth of just over 25%. 
Natural American Spirit has a loyal and growing franchise, and the brand's strength is based on its distinctive additive-free tobacco style, including those made with organic tobacco. 
Now turning to moist snuff, an American Snuff strong performance. Higher pricing and volume came through for the company in the second quarter, and operating income again grew by double digits. Moist snuff industry volumes continued to be impacted by consumer shift between various tobacco products, and the industry remains very competitive. Even so, American Snuff's second quarter moist snuff volume increased by 6%, almost double the moist industry volume growth. 
The company's moist snuff retail market share increased 1.1 percentage points to 33.8% in the second quarter. American Snuff flagship brand Grizzly, performed very well in the second quarter, with its retail market share increasing 1.3 percentage points to 31.1%, and this was on volume growth of just over 7%. 
Grizzly's momentum is being driven by its popular pouch style, which is the fastest-growing style of moist snuff and represents about 18% of the total category. The brand's Dark Wintergreen style, which was expanded nationally in March, is also performing well and contributing to Grizzly's growth. 
So as you can see, it's been a really terrific quarter for our company. And as I said earlier, there's a lot of work still to be done with the integration of Newport, but this kind of performance bodes very well for the rest of the year and beyond. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI had a stellar second quarter and first half over and above our completion of the acquisition of Lorillard and the related divestiture. RAI increased second quarter adjusted EPS by 14.6% from the prior ye
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. RAI had a stellar second quarter and first half over and above our completion of the acquisition of Lorillard and the related divestiture. 
RAI increased second quarter adjusted EPS by 14.6% from the prior year quarter to $1.02, supported by higher pricing across the board as well as the benefit from the completion of the federal tobacco-quota buyout in 2014. I would note that the completion of the Lorillard acquisition did not affect our adjusted EPS in the second quarter. 
As a reminder, our shares outstanding increased by 183 million to 715 million shares post-close. These adjusted results exclude a charge of $0.09 per share for transaction-related and financing cost, a charge of $0.12 per share for integration and implementation costs, and a gain of $2.57 per share for the divestiture. On a reported basis, second quarter EPS was $3.38, up more than 267% from the prior year quarter, driven by the gain on the divestiture to ITG Brands. 
First half adjusted EPS was $1.88, which was up 17.5% from the prior year period. These adjusted results exclude the previously mentioned items as well as a benefit of $0.08 per share from the 2003 NPM Adjustment claim, a charge of $0.13 per share for Engle Progeny lawsuit and a charge of $0.02 per share for tobacco-related and other litigation. 
On a reported basis, first half EPS was $4.20, up over 164%, driven by the gain on the divestiture to ITG Brands. RAI's adjusted operating margin also came in very strong again, increasing 4.7 percentage points to 42.1% for the quarter. 
Now I'll turn to our operating companies' performance where I'll focus on adjusted results. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results. R.J. Reynolds performed very well, reflecting about 2 weeks of Newport's results. The company's second quarter adjusted operating income increased by more than 19% to $832 million. That brought first half adjusted operating income to $1.5 billion. And the company's second quarter adjusted operating margin rose by 4.2 percentage points to 44.4%. 
With a moderation in cigarette industry volume declines in the first half of this year, the company's second quarter cigarette volumes were up 4.4% from the prior year quarter. This compares to cigarette industry volumes, which were up 1.9%. Wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 7.6 billion units at the end of second quarter, up about 1.6 billion from the prior year quarter, while R.J. Reynolds's inventories of approximately 2.4 billion were up about 800 million, reflecting the impact of additional Newport inventory resulting from the acquisition. 
When adjusting for these wholesale inventory changes, cigarette industry volumes declined approximately 0.8 percentage points in the second quarter. 
Santa Fe did another incredible job in the quarter, driving operating income up by 48.9% to $125 million, and that brought its first half to $217 million. The company's second quarter operating margin jumped by 7.6 percentage points to 57.2%. 
Now I'll turn to American Snuff. The company benefited from higher volume in addition to higher pricing and the second quarter operating income increased almost 18% to $130 million. That brought first half operating income to $248 million. The company's operating margin rose 3.1 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 59.4%. 
Before I open up the Q&A session, I'd like to cover some other financial items. Earlier this month, RAI successfully concluded the private offers to exchange the outstanding senior notes originally issued by Lorillard for newly issued notes of RAI. Together with our successful bond offering related to the acquisition itself, the company's long-term debt now stands at $17.6 billion. Our debt portfolio carries an average interest rate of 4.5% and an average maturity of 12.4 years. I do want to emphasize here that our near-term focus is to deleverage as efficiently and quickly as possible while maintaining appropriate financial flexibility. 
The company ended the quarter with cash balances of $4 billion, and that reflects the $1.4 billion MSA payment in April. Finally, I'd like to add some details to the important announcements that we made this morning. RAI's board approved a 2-for-1 stock split, which will be payable on August 31 to shareholders of record on August 17, and the 7.5% dividend increase will bring our annualized split-adjusted dividend to $1.44 or $0.36 on a quarterly basis. This reflects our commitment to our 75% dividend payout ratio following the Lorillard acquisition. 
Now that we've completed our acquisition of Lorillard, along with a very successful first half, RAI is increasing its full year adjusted earnings guidance to a range of $1.90 to $2 per share. This of course reflects the pending stock split. We expect to narrow this 2015 guidance range when we report third quarter results as we gain more insights into the dynamics of the new product portfolio, any potential impacts to the industry's competitive environment, and the pace of our anticipated cost synergies. Please note that this adjusted earnings guidance excludes all of the items I mentioned at the beginning of my discussion. Thank you. 
Now I'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Matthew Grainger of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, just 2 questions. This may be a topic for Friday, but Andrew, could you talk a bit about how you're thinking about the pacing of synergy realization? Whether you have any initial targets you can share, on what might be achievable as we're thinki
componenttext: So first, just 2 questions. This may be a topic for Friday, but Andrew, could you talk a bit about how you're thinking about the pacing of synergy realization? Whether you have any initial targets you can share, on what might be achievable as we're thinking about 2015? And what are some of the early milestones on the integration that we should be looking for that would allow you to accelerate the cost savings?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we look at this, nothing's really changed in terms of our outlook on the synergies. We still anticipate $800 million worth of cost synergies. We think $300 million of that will come over the next 18 months. In terms of the time frame there
componenttext: Yes, I think as we look at this, nothing's really changed in terms of our outlook on the synergies. We still anticipate $800 million worth of cost synergies. We think $300 million of that will come over the next 18 months. In terms of the time frame there, Matt, nothing has changed. We certainly will have a better view, I think, by the end of the third quarter on whether that 18 months is still a reasonable time frame or whether that's something we can accelerate forward. So the $800 million is still the number we're working off of at this time. And as far as the anticipated benefits,  as we've said, we will be accretive in the first full 12 months, and then we're looking at double-digit accretion in the second full year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I wanted to ask just for your assessment of the performance of -- for Susan, I guess, the performance of Newport across its various styles, just how you would characterize the brand's momentum right now across both its menthol styles
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I wanted to ask just for your assessment of the performance of -- for Susan, I guess, the performance of Newport across its various styles, just how you would characterize the brand's momentum right now across both its menthol styles and the red and gold variants, and just any initial thoughts on how you might approach those line extensions differently.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you know, Matt, I mean, we really haven't had it in the house that long but clearly, the momentum is primarily driven by its strength in menthol. And so we will evaluate the red and the gold styles, they certainly add to the overall market share of New
componenttext: As you know, Matt, I mean, we really haven't had it in the house that long but clearly, the momentum is primarily driven by its strength in menthol. And so we will evaluate the red and the gold styles, they certainly add to the overall market share of Newport, which has picked up 0.4 year-over-year. But we will look to energize and reinforce Newport and be focused, really, on the menthol portfolio.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lavery of CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned changing -- or I guess you mentioned some push on for trial and conversion on Pall Mall. Is there any change in your approach there? And can you talk a little bit about how it might be different versus what you've done with the brand in the
componenttext: You mentioned changing -- or I guess you mentioned some push on for trial and conversion on Pall Mall. Is there any change in your approach there? And can you talk a little bit about how it might be different versus what you've done with the brand in the past?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, I think we've talked about Pall Mall, which truly has this longer-lasting benefit. It has more tobacco, it has more puffs than any other value brand and equal or more than actually other premium products. So the big issue with Pall Mall is really
componenttext: Really, I think we've talked about Pall Mall, which truly has this longer-lasting benefit. It has more tobacco, it has more puffs than any other value brand and equal or more than actually other premium products. So the big issue with Pall Mall is really awareness of the proposition. And we've continued to grow that awareness, as obviously we've grown the brand but there is still enormous opportunity. And certainly, when we do research amongst consumers, if they knew about that proposition, they would choose Pall Mall. And so we will do some investment as we have done but we will do some investment to increase that proposition awareness. The other thing you need to think about, because Pall Mall did lose some market share year-over-year, we were also focused on ensuring that Winston, Salem and Kool were -- met the asset purchase agreement arrangement. And so we were spending to make sure that those market shares came through. And of course, that did, in effect, we pulled back a little bit on Pall Mall. And so we're confident that Pall Mall will continue to play a very important role in our portfolio, and we will balance profitability and market share.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then you also mentioned on capital allocation to focus on deleveraging but your near term maturities are relatively limited. How are you thinking about that?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, what I would say on that is we're focused on deleveraging. When we get to that 1.5 to 2.5 range, that's when we're going to revisit buybacks, that's when we'll revisit our dividend policy and start to look at all of those sorts of things and how
componenttext: Michael, what I would say on that is we're focused on deleveraging. When we get to that 1.5 to 2.5 range, that's when we're going to revisit buybacks, that's when we'll revisit our dividend policy and start to look at all of those sorts of things and how best to return value to shareholders. So really, our focus short term is to get back into that range of 1.5 to 2.5, and then we'll revisit some of those things.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on that, the dividend analysis is a part of that but you've said you want to get to the 75% payout and it looks like you've got some headroom there. If you have a line of sight, say, early next year and the dust has settled on some of
componenttext: And then just lastly on that, the dividend analysis is a part of that but you've said you want to get to the 75% payout and it looks like you've got some headroom there. If you have a line of sight, say, early next year and the dust has settled on some of the moving parts of the deal, is it possible you could have a move on the dividend? I know it's up to the board, but is that -- that's not necessarily just a year away, is that a fair way to -- is that a fair assumption to make?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that is a fair assumption. I think we're obviously committed to the 75% payout and that's something that we're going to be looking at on a regular basis to make sure we can deliver on that.
componenttext: I think that is a fair assumption. I think we're obviously committed to the 75% payout and that's something that we're going to be looking at on a regular basis to make sure we can deliver on that.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015

componenttext: And Michael, to be fair, we do recognize that the range that we're providing today, while it's 11% to 17%, is a wide range, and that is why we said that as we get into the end of the third quarter, we should be able to tighten that. And obviously, we'll have a clearer perspective on where it's going in 2016.

componenttext: So industry volumes continue to press quite nicely, even on an inventory adjusted basis. So Susan, I was hoping to hear your updated thoughts on your outlook for the industry and any incremental insights into what's driving this change in consumer behavior, please.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As you noted, industry volumes are up 1.9%,  but on an inventory adjusted basis, they're down about 0.8 percentage points. So as we think back to 2014, when we saw in the first half lots of inventory dollars going into vapor, we think that of course
componenttext: Sure. As you noted, industry volumes are up 1.9%,  but on an inventory adjusted basis, they're down about 0.8 percentage points. So as we think back to 2014, when we saw in the first half lots of inventory dollars going into vapor, we think that of course that, that has ended and now we've lapped those 6 months, the industry has performed very well. And we expect, I think, as the year unfolds, that the volume will decline year-over-year around 2%. And we'll just have to see how that unfolds in this third and fourth quarter.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. My second question has to do with the Camel brand, roughly, holding share but the share gains have decelerated a bit as I look at kind of the quarterly progression accounting for the change in your share presentation. Can you talk a little b
componenttext: That's great. My second question has to do with the Camel brand, roughly, holding share but the share gains have decelerated a bit as I look at kind of the quarterly progression accounting for the change in your share presentation. Can you talk a little bit about some of the competitive dynamics that may be impacting Camel?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean we were happy with Camel, I mean, volume up 3.5%. And as you mentioned, the change in the share metrics obviously impacted the year-over-year comparable, that's all in there on a pro forma basis. So Camel has continued to do very well. We are
componenttext: Yes. I mean we were happy with Camel, I mean, volume up 3.5%. And as you mentioned, the change in the share metrics obviously impacted the year-over-year comparable, that's all in there on a pro forma basis. So Camel has continued to do very well. We are very happy with the menthol styles performing well. And I did mention before, of course, there's always a little bit of impact when we were focusing on Winston and Kool. And so that can touch everybody a little bit, but now those brands have been divested and Camel has some exciting programs in the second half. So we are -- continue to be confident on Camel's opportunity.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. My last question for Andrew, please. The margin expansion that Santa Fe delivered, clearly, exceptional. Can you give us a framework for thinking about margin progression for that business in the back half of the year?
componenttext: That's great. My last question for Andrew, please. The margin expansion that Santa Fe delivered, clearly, exceptional. Can you give us a framework for thinking about margin progression for that business in the back half of the year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the biggest element here, Vivien, is obviously, we'll be lapping the tobacco-quota buyout in the fourth quarter so there will be a bit of an adjustment there. But generally, what we're looking at is volume and pricing for Santa Fe and that's
componenttext: Yes, I think the biggest element here, Vivien, is obviously, we'll be lapping the tobacco-quota buyout in the fourth quarter so there will be a bit of an adjustment there. But generally, what we're looking at is volume and pricing for Santa Fe and that's really driving everything. So we'll obviously have a pullback based on the lapping of the tobacco-quota buyout, but overall, that's pretty much the math behind it.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vivien, the other thing I thought I'd add, you asked me a little bit about consumers in the context of this volume, we did see, the moist industry was up about 3% in this quarter, but we continue to see a lot of consumers trying different kinds of product
componenttext: Vivien, the other thing I thought I'd add, you asked me a little bit about consumers in the context of this volume, we did see, the moist industry was up about 3% in this quarter, but we continue to see a lot of consumers trying different kinds of products, particularly moist consumers, very interested in vapor, interested in other tobacco product types. And of course, as we know, many moist users also smoke cigarettes. And we have seen continuation of gas prices have been good. We hear C-store traffic is good. And so there's been a resulting benefit in premium mix, as well as in overall consumption.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Owen Bennett of Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Owen Bennett of Nomura.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on the vapor. Just wondering if you could comment on the e-vapor performance. It looks like it could have become profitable in the quarter based on the all of that segment. I'm just wondering if it's more driven by investment being pulled
componenttext: Just a quick one on the vapor. Just wondering if you could comment on the e-vapor performance. It looks like it could have become profitable in the quarter based on the all of that segment. I'm just wondering if it's more driven by investment being pulled back now or top line momentum?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Owen. I would describe the vapor segment, and there's been a lot written about it, it is relatively stable. VUSE continues to be the #1 e-cigarette in gas convenience and vapor is probably 5% or 5%-plus of total tobacco today, when you add in all
componenttext: Thanks, Owen. I would describe the vapor segment, and there's been a lot written about it, it is relatively stable. VUSE continues to be the #1 e-cigarette in gas convenience and vapor is probably 5% or 5%-plus of total tobacco today, when you add in all the vape shops and all forms of vapor. Having said that, in terms of our financials on VUSE, we are lapping the national rollout, and of course, the expense in this quarter is certainly much lower than the same period last year. We will continue to invest in VUSE, and we will make appropriate investments as we work to continue to add innovation to that category.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So do you think -- I mean, is there any time frame on it when it will become more consistently profitable, I guess?
componenttext: Okay. So do you think -- I mean, is there any time frame on it when it will become more consistently profitable, I guess?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's not really a specific time frame. We are happy with its contribution. And as I said, we will continue to innovate in this space to offer consumers choice.
componenttext: There's not really a specific time frame. We are happy with its contribution. And as I said, we will continue to innovate in this space to offer consumers choice.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, I just want to make sure I've get the pricing math right. So we're looking at about 6-ish percent in terms of net price realizations in the cigarette business, and that's accounting for Newport coming in but the divested bran
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, I just want to make sure I've get the pricing math right. So we're looking at about 6-ish percent in terms of net price realizations in the cigarette business, and that's accounting for Newport coming in but the divested brands coming out. So I guess the question is, the divested brands going out, did they have similar level of pricing as Newport? That's the first question, just so I can get that right. And then the second question is really on the regulatory side. So the TPSAC has given their viewpoint on modified risk but the FDA has not. And Susan, I was just wondering if maybe you could opine on your thoughts on how the FDA is thinking about this whole situation.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nik, let me take the first question on net price realization. You're looking at that right. RJRT was 6.1% for the quarter. Santa Fe was 3.2% for the quarter. So on the cigarette business, the 6% is a good number. I think when you look at the impact of New
componenttext: Nik, let me take the first question on net price realization. You're looking at that right. RJRT was 6.1% for the quarter. Santa Fe was 3.2% for the quarter. So on the cigarette business, the 6% is a good number. I think when you look at the impact of Newport, I would say that had very minimal impact on the overall net price realization. It was obviously only 2 weeks, and looking at the divested brand's numbers, I would say it was minimal in the quarter, minimal impact from Newport.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Nik, on the other question, we continue to believe that the deeming regs will come out some time this summer. Summer is beginning to go past, but that's the best information that we have. And of course, we feel very confident that we can respond to wh
componenttext: And Nik, on the other question, we continue to believe that the deeming regs will come out some time this summer. Summer is beginning to go past, but that's the best information that we have. And of course, we feel very confident that we can respond to whatever those regs are.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Growe of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Growe of Stifel.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 follow-ups, if I could, from the earlier questions. And not to be so short-term focused, but is there earnings accretion coming through from the Lorillard acquisition here in the second half that you roll over here in 2015?
componenttext: I just had 2 follow-ups, if I could, from the earlier questions. And not to be so short-term focused, but is there earnings accretion coming through from the Lorillard acquisition here in the second half that you roll over here in 2015?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: There will be, yes. Although as we've said, we expect that in the first 12 months, there will be some accretion in the back half of this year, yes.
componenttext: There will be, yes. Although as we've said, we expect that in the first 12 months, there will be some accretion in the back half of this year, yes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I just want to be sure of that. And I was also curious in relation to Camel, is the capsule technology and its presence in menthol, is that complementary to Newport? Are you to change your sort of marketing strategy for Camel going forward just give
componenttext: Okay. I just want to be sure of that. And I was also curious in relation to Camel, is the capsule technology and its presence in menthol, is that complementary to Newport? Are you to change your sort of marketing strategy for Camel going forward just given your now very large presence in the menthol category?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're getting to know very well now the Newport consumer, and the most important thing is to look at the consumers for Newport and the consumers for Camel. There actually is not a lot of overlap. And so we see opportunities for both brands, and we will co
componenttext: We're getting to know very well now the Newport consumer, and the most important thing is to look at the consumers for Newport and the consumers for Camel. There actually is not a lot of overlap. And so we see opportunities for both brands, and we will continue to refine that strategy going forward.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe 1 quick follow-up on -- there was a question on like debt-to-EBITDA and debt pay down, I know that's a focus right now, is there a certain threshold where -- and not necessarily that you like share repurchase but the company is m
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe 1 quick follow-up on -- there was a question on like debt-to-EBITDA and debt pay down, I know that's a focus right now, is there a certain threshold where -- and not necessarily that you like share repurchase but the company is more comfortable, is it 2x debt to EBITDA that you'd like to get back to before you start thinking about share repurchase activity? Is there a hard line there?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we're looking at 2.5 is the number that we've talked about getting back to before we start to evaluate the options on share repurchase. So we like to operate in that 1.5 to 2.5 range. But certainly, if we get to 2.5, that's sort of the th
componenttext: Well, certainly, we're looking at 2.5 is the number that we've talked about getting back to before we start to evaluate the options on share repurchase. So we like to operate in that 1.5 to 2.5 range. But certainly, if we get to 2.5, that's sort of the threshold that we would start to evaluate whether it be share repurchase or potentially, dividend policy change, back to our 80% that we had historically.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Andrew, just a couple of follow-up from my end as well. Just in terms of the quarter, I know you said the deal didn't really impact the earnings number, but can you just give us the impact on revenue and operating income?
componenttext: So Andrew, just a couple of follow-up from my end as well. Just in terms of the quarter, I know you said the deal didn't really impact the earnings number, but can you just give us the impact on revenue and operating income?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look at net sales, there was about a 6% impact from the acquisition. And on the net income side, it was about 6%. And then obviously, the diluted shares outstanding changed about 6.8%.
componenttext: Sure. If you look at net sales, there was about a 6% impact from the acquisition. And on the net income side, it was about 6%. And then obviously, the diluted shares outstanding changed about 6.8%.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The net income impact is 6%. Do you have the operating income impact?
componenttext: The net income impact is 6%. Do you have the operating income impact?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Operating income was 9%.
componenttext: Operating income was 9%.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the guidance, I think you just answered Chris's question about the accretion from Lorillard being some of the drivers, but in terms of if we look at your underlying results, the increased guidance for the year, does that also include som
componenttext: Okay. And then on the guidance, I think you just answered Chris's question about the accretion from Lorillard being some of the drivers, but in terms of if we look at your underlying results, the increased guidance for the year, does that also include some positive performance in terms of volume and pricing and margin in terms of your underlying performance as well?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly. That takes into account the outlook for the year. We think we obviously had a very good first half of the year. And it does take into account the accretion that we're planning to have in the back half of the year, as well as just overall
componenttext: Well, certainly. That takes into account the outlook for the year. We think we obviously had a very good first half of the year. And it does take into account the accretion that we're planning to have in the back half of the year, as well as just overall performance. As Susan said, one of the things that we will be looking at with industry volumes up 1.9% in the first half. The second half, we do anticipate being a bit different than that because we will be lapping some of the moderation of the industry volume decline, as well as we will be lapping the federal tobacco-quota buyout ending in October. So both of those things have been taken into account.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Susan, maybe just your perspective on with some of the changes in terms of the brand ownership with Imperial and obviously, your ownership of Newport, just your assessment of how you envision the competitive dynamics sort of evolving in the
componenttext: Okay. And then Susan, maybe just your perspective on with some of the changes in terms of the brand ownership with Imperial and obviously, your ownership of Newport, just your assessment of how you envision the competitive dynamics sort of evolving in the next 6 to 12 months. And then, as you now become -- as your brand mix is now a bit more premium, is there any change to just in terms of how you think about your pricing and promotional strategies for your total brand portfolio?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, it's a little early to describe all that. We will go into some more details in the meetings later this week and early next week and those will also be webcast. But I would say obviously, we are very excited to have Newport in the house, very excit
componenttext: I mean, it's a little early to describe all that. We will go into some more details in the meetings later this week and early next week and those will also be webcast. But I would say obviously, we are very excited to have Newport in the house, very excited about the opportunity for Newport. And as you referenced, we sit here with 90%, 92% of our volume now in the growth brand, with an enhanced premium mix. And we will certainly go to market to compete in those must-win segments. And we'll also take a look -- some of you read through the asset purchase agreements and the surrounding terms, but we are in sort of a standstill period at retail with ITG Brands. And that will evolve over the next 6 months. And we'll explain some of those things, as I said, as the week goes on. But suffice it to say that we are getting to know the Newport consumer. We've picked up 50,000 additional retail contracts, many new customers and a significant database of those customers, and so we are working on our strategies to optimize our performance. And I think that you'll see a great run going forward.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have 2 questions. I guess I was hoping you could talk a little bit more on the manufacturing of Newport and why this transition won't take place until next year. Susan, I think you mentioned later next year? So should we assume third or fourth quar
componenttext: I just have 2 questions. I guess I was hoping you could talk a little bit more on the manufacturing of Newport and why this transition won't take place until next year. Susan, I think you mentioned later next year? So should we assume third or fourth quarter? And I guess, I'm curious why this is taking so long.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bonnie. We scheduled this for 18 months. We are physically moving the machines that made Newport from Greensboro into our factory in Tobaccoville, and this absolutely ensures that we will meet the FDA requirements to produce exactly the same specifi
componenttext: Sure, Bonnie. We scheduled this for 18 months. We are physically moving the machines that made Newport from Greensboro into our factory in Tobaccoville, and this absolutely ensures that we will meet the FDA requirements to produce exactly the same specification. And so we are moving machine every couple of weeks, but it takes time to move those machines, and then we have complexes that are moving to Greensboro to produce Winston-Salem and Kool. And so that has all been lined up. The volume will fold in here. So it doesn't -- it won't come exactly smoothly, and we'll be prepared, as Andrew said, I think, that for the back of the third quarter, we'll be able to give you a little more information about that. But we have allowed the right amount of time to ensure that we can exactly reproduce. And so in that interim, we have a reciprocal manufacturing agreement with ITG Brands. We are making Winston, Salem and Kool for them, and they are making Newport for us. And once that volume all gets into Tobaccoville, of course, we will recognize quite a significant operational efficiency and cost base.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's really a second half '16 by the time you're finished with this transition?
componenttext: So it's really a second half '16 by the time you're finished with this transition?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is.
componenttext: Yes, it is.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then are you, just quickly, are you seeing any disruptions at this point so far with this reciprocal agreement?
componenttext: And then are you, just quickly, are you seeing any disruptions at this point so far with this reciprocal agreement?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are not. I think there's been some rumblings about Newport inventory. And actually, to be honest with you,  the total inventory of Newport that is out in the trade is absolutely standard level. It's not exactly all equally placed as it happens. And so
componenttext: We are not. I think there's been some rumblings about Newport inventory. And actually, to be honest with you,  the total inventory of Newport that is out in the trade is absolutely standard level. It's not exactly all equally placed as it happens. And so we have not heard of any concerns about retail out of stocks, but there have been some wholesalers that put things on quota. And it was interesting because we closed that transaction on June 12 and we took orders on the Monday. So we managed that transition very well. But we moved, for instance, from a 1-day to a 3-day delivery, so we had wholesalers ordering more product upfront. We also probably had wholesalers that were worried it wouldn't work, so they ordered a lot of product upfront. And then there were a couple of states where there were tax increases where there was no floor tax, and they ordered a lot upfront. So we are very confident in the manufacturing agreement and all volumes are intact, it's just that they're finding their way to the right places in this early stage.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we're working to smooth out that inventory. I think that's -- should be considered sort of a short-term issue.
componenttext: Yes. And we're working to smooth out that inventory. I think that's -- should be considered sort of a short-term issue.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's good to hear. And then my final question is sort of a follow on, on Natural American Spirit, which, again, continues to perform very well. So curious to hear where these share gains are being sourced from. And then could you maybe drill down
componenttext: Okay. That's good to hear. And then my final question is sort of a follow on, on Natural American Spirit, which, again, continues to perform very well. So curious to hear where these share gains are being sourced from. And then could you maybe drill down on the strength of the brand and how much this has been a function of the stronger tobacco consumer versus some of your stepped-up promotions behind the brand? Because I think, as you mentioned earlier, the stepped-up promo has probably contributed to your lower net price realization for the brand.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well partly, remember, that's off of a much higher base. So the NAS does not discount and the promotions are trial promotion only. I would say the following: we would say that the increase in sales volume at NAS is more than half same store, same style. A
componenttext: Well partly, remember, that's off of a much higher base. So the NAS does not discount and the promotions are trial promotion only. I would say the following: we would say that the increase in sales volume at NAS is more than half same store, same style. And so it really continues to resonate with consumers. Now to your point, the whole premium segment is doing well amongst consumers, but NAS particularly, has such a relevant positioning for today's consumer and is a differentiated positioning. And we'll talk again a little bit more about that on these upcoming webcasts and in the meetings that we're going to hold Friday and Monday. But NAS continues to go from strength to strength. It's gaining market share in every state. And I think it's reached that sort of critical mass tipping point in many of the very trendsetting cities here in the U.S. So we are very bullish about it continuing to run.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, on the marketing support, promotional support side, that has not changed significantly year-over-year. That's been pretty consistent all the way through.
componenttext: And I would just add, on the marketing support, promotional support side, that has not changed significantly year-over-year. That's been pretty consistent all the way through.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Marshall of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Marshall of Barclays.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of quick follow-up questions. We haven't talked a whole lot about specific revenue synergies with the acquisition. You have talked a little bit about how Camel and Newport are both pretty complementary, also from a geographic perspecti
componenttext: I just had a couple of quick follow-up questions. We haven't talked a whole lot about specific revenue synergies with the acquisition. You have talked a little bit about how Camel and Newport are both pretty complementary, also from a geographic perspective, they're pretty complementary. So I was curious if we could get your thoughts on the potential for geographic expansion for Newport. I know it's still early days but just how you're thinking about that going forward. And just as a follow-up, how to ensure, from a sales force perspective, that prioritizing the 2 brands, Camel and Newport, both are doing very well, obviously, and how you keep the focus on both brands separately.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. I think, certainly, there are opportunities for revenue synergies. If you think about it, Newport has almost doubled its sales force representation in this transaction. And so there are just that many more people out there representing Newport
componenttext: Sure, Bill. I think, certainly, there are opportunities for revenue synergies. If you think about it, Newport has almost doubled its sales force representation in this transaction. And so there are just that many more people out there representing Newport in that many more stores. We are very confident that our sales force, with prioritized programs, will focus on our priority brands. There is certainly, geographic complementarity. And as we will talk a little bit more about how this will unfold in terms of the retail universe over the next 9 to 12 months as we get into these meetings later in the week. But we are confident we do believe that we can accelerate the growth of Newport, and specific plans on how that will happen will unfold by the end of this year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta of Barclays.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, a housekeeping item. The prospectus related to your debt issuance indicated that you had $1.1 billion in revolver borrowings outstanding around mid-June, curious if that was still the case at month's end. And then secondly, if you look at sort of y
componenttext: First, a housekeeping item. The prospectus related to your debt issuance indicated that you had $1.1 billion in revolver borrowings outstanding around mid-June, curious if that was still the case at month's end. And then secondly, if you look at sort of your schedule for debt maturities, it looks like you don't get back to that 1.5 to 2.5x range potentially into 2018. I wanted to make sure that, that's sort of directionally the right way to think about it or if there's potential to hit that range a little sooner.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- to answer your first question, yes, that has been paid back, the $1.1 billion was paid back in June. And so that is reflected in the numbers. And I think you're looking at it exactly right, 2018. If we continue to pay that debt down as it
componenttext: Yes, I think -- to answer your first question, yes, that has been paid back, the $1.1 billion was paid back in June. And so that is reflected in the numbers. And I think you're looking at it exactly right, 2018. If we continue to pay that debt down as it matures, that 2018 is the time frame that, that would be in.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2015

componenttext: That makes more sense. And did you still think that it would happen in 3Q? Or is that not necessarily the case?

componenttext: Adam, if you'll indulge me, we will cover that this Friday in New York and next Monday in London, and it will be webcast.
