headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Terrific. And then a question on the substantial equivalence and your decision to pull Camel Whites voluntarily. Do you feel like there's anything else in the system that could be at risk? Or do you feel like you've cleaned up the portfolio from an SC per
componenttext: Terrific. And then a question on the substantial equivalence and your decision to pull Camel Whites voluntarily. Do you feel like there's anything else in the system that could be at risk? Or do you feel like you've cleaned up the portfolio from an SC perspective?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, from those SC rulings, Vivien, we are totally clean. Those Camel White styles had similar -- the same characteristics as the ruling on the Pall Mall styles, and so that was the decision that we took. And as I stated, we disagree with the ruling
componenttext: Certainly, from those SC rulings, Vivien, we are totally clean. Those Camel White styles had similar -- the same characteristics as the ruling on the Pall Mall styles, and so that was the decision that we took. And as I stated, we disagree with the ruling. We will look forward to working with the FDA on the process. And we'll see where we go from here. But certainly, we are clean. And as you know, that combined market share was about 0.34. And as I stated, we do expect that we will recapture most of that volume with other styles in the family.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Terrific. That's very helpful. If I could just squeeze in one last one. Obviously, industry volumes continue to track very well. Susan, on the last call, you indicated that you thought industry volumes could be down 2%. So I was wondering if you could upd
componenttext: Terrific. That's very helpful. If I could just squeeze in one last one. Obviously, industry volumes continue to track very well. Susan, on the last call, you indicated that you thought industry volumes could be down 2%. So I was wondering if you could update that. And additionally, if you could offer any commentary at all on the volume trends that you're seeing in Hawaii, just because of the implementation of the new legal purchase age please.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll say, as we saw the quarter was down 2.2%, 0.8% on an adjusted basis, when we think about it, we are expecting -- if you look back over the years, and during the recessionary period, where people were mixing down, we saw 3% to 4% of cigarette de
componenttext: Sure. I'll say, as we saw the quarter was down 2.2%, 0.8% on an adjusted basis, when we think about it, we are expecting -- if you look back over the years, and during the recessionary period, where people were mixing down, we saw 3% to 4% of cigarette decline. And in the really strong years, we've seen, like this year, it's been particularly strong, where the economy -- we've had very good economic tailwinds for our consumers. But probably, the average of this 2% to 4% decline rate is where we should look as we go forward. And obviously, we report on that every quarter. We don't -- we have not yet been able to dissect Hawaii. As you know, it's a very small state, and we'll certainly look at those results. What's interesting and the perspective on that is that we have worked with the states for years to reduce underage smoking. And we've been very successful getting laws in place. The vast majority of volume that is used by underage is bought for them by adults. So the outcome of the 21 versus 18, I don't think we can see anything yet with that. There are better ways to address it. But having said that, that's the state's call. But we will be following that. And obviously, we'll be following if there's any other momentum as we go forward.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the COGS side, so -- I guess, I'm just trying to understand how the cost transferred to Imperial would have shown up in the quarter, because if I sort of look back at your base, RJR -- Reynolds' COGS and then add Lorillard's COGS, I'm getting kind of $574 million or $590 million. headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's right. So the cost essentially have come out of the business. That's $500 million on an annualized basis, of course. So we're basically tracking right on that. So the impact from the additional synergies that we'd talked about, as I sa
componenttext: Yes. I think that's right. So the cost essentially have come out of the business. That's $500 million on an annualized basis, of course. So we're basically tracking right on that. So the impact from the additional synergies that we'd talked about, as I said earlier, will be back-ended. There are some that are -- will show up this year, but it's going to be minimal. The majority of the first year -- first full year synergies will come in the second 6 months as the volume transitions out of the Lorillard facility.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then, Susan, just a question about Camel franchise, and I know that you've talked about your efforts to improve the brand equity of that franchise. But just wanted to see if you can kind of point to what you're doing more specifically. If
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then, Susan, just a question about Camel franchise, and I know that you've talked about your efforts to improve the brand equity of that franchise. But just wanted to see if you can kind of point to what you're doing more specifically. If you look at some of the share trends, obviously, it's been a little bit softer in the context of the glowing premium segments. So what do you think is causing a little bit of that softness, and kind of what are you doing exactly to drive better growth on the Camel franchise?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're actually pleased with Camel's performance. Of course, it did take a little hit this quarter from those SEs, those non-equivalent styles. So that did have a small impact on the Camel brand, with Camel Bold and the Camel White styles. So we feel very
componenttext: We're actually pleased with Camel's performance. Of course, it did take a little hit this quarter from those SEs, those non-equivalent styles. So that did have a small impact on the Camel brand, with Camel Bold and the Camel White styles. So we feel very good about Camel. We are very excited about the new retail contracts for Camel, which I know goes beyond the equity expiration. But we are excited about the expanded presence for Camel on the Eastern side of the U.S., which will start in November. So the whole industry had mixed up a bit. Premium is up certainly year-over-year. And of course, we benefited substantially with NAS and Newport, and Camel held its own. So we're working, as Debra talked about, I think, the last time we met at the Investor Day, at looking at how that family will present itself going forward and making sure that we have the most relevant style. But we continue to be pleased with Camel Menthol's performance, Camel Crush's performance, and the family is in good shape.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions. Smokeless, just want to get some context kind of what's going in the category. Looks like volumes have rebounded nicely, but pricing was negative. So just state the union there and how long that will continue. And then just a big picture q
componenttext: So 2 questions. Smokeless, just want to get some context kind of what's going in the category. Looks like volumes have rebounded nicely, but pricing was negative. So just state the union there and how long that will continue. And then just a big picture question on e-cigarettes. I see the other line is still in negative territory. I know you guys said that you'll continue to spend as you see fit. So just curious on the strategy there. I mean, are you seeing competitors exit the market and so you feel like there's a window of opportunity to kind of consolidate the shelf? Any perspective you can share on the strategy behind the e-cig's spend?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good. Nik, I'll take, I guess, first shot at the question. With regard to the American Snuff company, obviously, we showed an adjusted operating income of 3.4%. A lot of that was driven by timing of marketing activity. And if you go back and you look
componenttext: Very good. Nik, I'll take, I guess, first shot at the question. With regard to the American Snuff company, obviously, we showed an adjusted operating income of 3.4%. A lot of that was driven by timing of marketing activity. And if you go back and you look historically, we've had some up and downs by the quarter, but, really, I think I'd point you back to the year-to-date of 12.4%. We're very happy with that. Some of this was just a matter of timing in terms of some of our marketing expense. So nothing beyond that. We feel very good about the volumes, obviously, coming through. And I would look at the year-to-date as a more -- a better indicator of sort of where we are with the business. With regard to the electronic cigarettes and VUSE, yes, so we've seen some improvements there. Obviously, we're focused on productivity improvements. We've consolidated the operations. All of that is moving in that direction. But as we've talked about previously, we want to be prudent with our investments. We certainly want to invest based on the opportunity that we see in the marketplace. And there are certainly opportunities long term for this category. I think we'd been prudent. We're now #1 on the c-store channel by a significant margin. We continue to take market share from our competitors. And I think we're going to continue to read the market and see what opportunities present themselves.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Of course, I'd remind you, this quarter, we did launch the 4 new flavors, and we're getting some enthusiastic response. And of course, that gives VUSE a slightly stronger footprint at retail. And you do see retailers consolidating certainly the categ
componenttext: Yes. Of course, I'd remind you, this quarter, we did launch the 4 new flavors, and we're getting some enthusiastic response. And of course, that gives VUSE a slightly stronger footprint at retail. And you do see retailers consolidating certainly the category, certainly traditional retailers. And so we're investing prudently. But it's important that VUSE remains -- we said that our objective was to be the vapor authority, and then to invest in other innovative products for consumers down the pipeline is also important.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then keep in mind, the numbers that you're looking at do include close to $100 million of costs that were associated with the consolidation of facilities.
componenttext: And then keep in mind, the numbers that you're looking at do include close to $100 million of costs that were associated with the consolidation of facilities.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And if I can ask just one more question. In terms of the take-up of the new contract that you guys will be launching in November. When will you have a good understanding of what the take-up rate is for those contracts?
componenttext: Got you. And if I can ask just one more question. In terms of the take-up of the new contract that you guys will be launching in November. When will you have a good understanding of what the take-up rate is for those contracts?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way these work, we are pleased with the results so far. It's not uncommon at all that a lot comes flurrying in, in the last 2 weeks. So I think the cutoff day is November 15. And so we will certainly know more, certainly, as we come into the -- to inv
componenttext: The way these work, we are pleased with the results so far. It's not uncommon at all that a lot comes flurrying in, in the last 2 weeks. So I think the cutoff day is November 15. And so we will certainly know more, certainly, as we come into the -- to invest -- our Investor Days that are set up for November, we will have much more clarity. So it -- but we are encouraged. And of course, as you know, it's public that Newport is part of our EDLP contract, and so retailers are evaluating their participation based on their business model. So we will be able to update further in a couple of weeks.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Lavery with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up, Andrew, with something I think you just said a minute ago that the VUSE costs included about $100 million of -- from consolidating production. Was that in the quarter or year-to-date? And is that a number you've excluded as par
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up, Andrew, with something I think you just said a minute ago that the VUSE costs included about $100 million of -- from consolidating production. Was that in the quarter or year-to-date? And is that a number you've excluded as part of adjusted? Or is that in the adjusted number?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's in the quarter. So of the $127 million loss in all other that's in the quarter, and that is an adjustment that we have made for third quarter. So that will come out.
componenttext: Yes, that's in the quarter. So of the $127 million loss in all other that's in the quarter, and that is an adjustment that we have made for third quarter. So that will come out.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, no problem. And I just wanted to talk a little bit about Pall Mall. Last quarter especially, you were talking about some of the focus on driving trial and conversion there. Obviously, it's held share sequentially. But could you give a sense of
componenttext: All right, no problem. And I just wanted to talk a little bit about Pall Mall. Last quarter especially, you were talking about some of the focus on driving trial and conversion there. Obviously, it's held share sequentially. But could you give a sense of somewhat how you feel like that progress is going?  Do you expect share gains to return there? Or do you think that, that's sort of a necessary spend to hold share with some -- the new competitive environment? Or how do you think about that brand? And what are your marketing efforts are likely to give you?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Michael. As we said and as you pointed out, it was flat quarter-over-quarter. So this 0.3 was lost, actually, early on in the year and at the back end of last year. Now -- and remember that the whole industry, the premium mix is improving. And so as
componenttext: Sure, Michael. As we said and as you pointed out, it was flat quarter-over-quarter. So this 0.3 was lost, actually, early on in the year and at the back end of last year. Now -- and remember that the whole industry, the premium mix is improving. And so as consumers have traded up to premium, and of course, we benefit significantly now with Newport as well as NAS and Camel in the portfolio. So we feel that Pall Mall is playing its role. We're happy with its market share performance. It's important to have a strong value property, because the economics can change and people can start down-trading to a value brand. But we are very happy with Pall Mall. And we do believe, actually, that as we expand these EDLP contracts, these merchandising contracts, beginning next month, the Pall Mall will benefit from that, because it will be the everyday low-priced brand in more stores. And so we will obviously update that as we go through the first quarter. But we don't expect Pall Mall to continue to decline. But of course, we also like the premiumization of the category. So we're happy with that balance of profit and share as we speak.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just back on Camel White, can you describe a little bit more what the similarities were with the NSE products? Is it menthol level? Is it the filter? What is it that made you think it was -- it made sense to proactively go ahead and pu
componenttext: That's helpful. And just back on Camel White, can you describe a little bit more what the similarities were with the NSE products? Is it menthol level? Is it the filter? What is it that made you think it was -- it made sense to proactively go ahead and pull that instead of maybe just even waiting until -- if the FDA hadn't done something yet, were you convinced that they were going to get around to it? Or how -- what was your thinking around all that?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and yes. The thinking was -- the characteristics of Camel White across the board, the product was the same as the Pall Mall style. And therefore, our determination was that -- what the FDA ruled on was that product versus its predicate. And so it was
componenttext: Yes, and yes. The thinking was -- the characteristics of Camel White across the board, the product was the same as the Pall Mall style. And therefore, our determination was that -- what the FDA ruled on was that product versus its predicate. And so it was beholden and prudent on our side to take that product off the market. And that's what we did. And as I've said, we disagree with the ruling and we want to understand this process. And we're pursuing all of our options. But that was the right decision, and that's why we took Camel White out.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just 2 questions. First, 2 clarifications, I guess, for Andrew, and then just one follow-up. So Andrew, I just wanted to come back to the inventory numbers and the sort of underlying volume numbers you talked about earlier. You mentioned that inventory
componenttext: So just 2 questions. First, 2 clarifications, I guess, for Andrew, and then just one follow-up. So Andrew, I just wanted to come back to the inventory numbers and the sort of underlying volume numbers you talked about earlier. You mentioned that inventory at the industry level was up about 600 million units year-on-year. But then industry volumes were down 80 basis points versus reported industry volumes, down 2.2%, which would suggest the year-on-year inventory reduction. So I guess, could you just help me reconcile those numbers? Does that -- I'm just having trouble squaring those 2.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the inventory change obviously is versus last year's third quarter. Obviously, when we look at the third quarter volume performance, that looks at the inventory adjustments within the quarter. So I'd be happy to take that offline, and we can work
componenttext: Yes. So the inventory change obviously is versus last year's third quarter. Obviously, when we look at the third quarter volume performance, that looks at the inventory adjustments within the quarter. So I'd be happy to take that offline, and we can work through that with you. But obviously, the 600 million is versus third quarter last year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take another look and follow up offline as well. And then inventory levels, generally, they're still quite a bit higher than they were in Q1. Should we think of them as being somewhat normalized now? Or are they still at elevated levels overall
componenttext: Okay. I'll take another look and follow up offline as well. And then inventory levels, generally, they're still quite a bit higher than they were in Q1. Should we think of them as being somewhat normalized now? Or are they still at elevated levels overall?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say our inventory is normalized for the new portfolio as you look at that today. The industry looks to be elevated versus year end last year for sure.
componenttext: I would say our inventory is normalized for the new portfolio as you look at that today. The industry looks to be elevated versus year end last year for sure.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the 5% underlying volume number you mentioned earlier, could you just clarify what that represents?
componenttext: Okay. And then just the 5% underlying volume number you mentioned earlier, could you just clarify what that represents?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's basically just an estimate of the impact of the acquisition. So 5% additional volume in the quarter. Again, and I do want to highlight this because it is an estimate and it's something that's going to get more difficult as we go forward as cha
componenttext: Yes. That's basically just an estimate of the impact of the acquisition. So 5% additional volume in the quarter. Again, and I do want to highlight this because it is an estimate and it's something that's going to get more difficult as we go forward as changes in all of these products occur, but we are trying to track and make sure that we are achieving all of the synergies and looking at are we getting the impact from the acquisition that we anticipated. We're right on track. Synergies are coming in. The volumes are coming in. We're very happy with the performance of Newport in the third quarter. And I think the 5% is an estimate that we're looking at in terms of impact of the acquisition on the volumes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Andrew. And then just a broader question about the competitive environment in full flavor menthol. I think there's some new line extensions coming to market in the next several weeks. So just any observations, are you seeing any increase in competit
componenttext: Okay, Andrew. And then just a broader question about the competitive environment in full flavor menthol. I think there's some new line extensions coming to market in the next several weeks. So just any observations, are you seeing any increase in competitive intensity during this initial period of ownership when you're still updating your trade contracts?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's really stage competitive, and of course, we have honored all of Lorillard's commitments to the retailers. We have put in money where we thought that was necessary. And of course, we're going into our new contract period, and Newport will be f
componenttext: I think it's really stage competitive, and of course, we have honored all of Lorillard's commitments to the retailers. We have put in money where we thought that was necessary. And of course, we're going into our new contract period, and Newport will be featured in more stores. But the premium menthol space has been very competitive for quite a long time. And of course, Camel, if from our portfolio, has been battling it out with our friends in Richmond forever. And now, of course, we have Newport in our stable. So we are very confident. And we haven't seen any changes in the segment overall. That segment is still strong, and it's still growing. So we'll see how that unfolds as the new contracts come into place and whatever new styles may be coming.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have a couple of follow-ups for you, if I could. I just wanted to get a better sense and not so much around 4Q or even 1Q. But once the new retail contracts are in place, I assume you're going to tell me that both Newport and Camel should benefit f
componenttext: I just have a couple of follow-ups for you, if I could. I just wanted to get a better sense and not so much around 4Q or even 1Q. But once the new retail contracts are in place, I assume you're going to tell me that both Newport and Camel should benefit from that. What I'm trying to get a sense of is, is one benefiting more than the other? You have the sort of new customers or new accounts that, perhaps, Camel could benefit from in the East Coast, and likewise, Newport could benefit from Camel -- contracts of Camel. Is there one that benefits more than the other? Or one maybe don't want to change too much like those existing Newport customers, perhaps you won't see much change there?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think they both will benefit, there's no doubt. Now Newport, in absolute terms, is a bigger brand where it is big. And so -- but I really am excited as we've shown you the map, where we get a very balanced national market share, although it is made up o
componenttext: I think they both will benefit, there's no doubt. Now Newport, in absolute terms, is a bigger brand where it is big. And so -- but I really am excited as we've shown you the map, where we get a very balanced national market share, although it is made up of different parts of our portfolio. And therefore, the merchandising opportunity to give Camel some space in the Northeast and give Newport some more space in the West, they will both benefit from that in their strongholds. In the middle of the country, perhaps, where neither of them -- there may not be as much benefit, because they're both sort of there. But I do believe on the coast, that both brands will benefit. And from retail presence, from merchandising, from the display and where that display is located, I think there's quite a bit of opportunity. And our -- I know our trade marketing guys can't wait to get started resetting the racks, and so we look forward to that unfolding over the next few months.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I would just add that I also think Pall Mall will benefit, particularly on the East Coast, given some of the new contracts that we picked up with the Lorillard business as well as our new contract, with Newport included, should benefit Pall Mall as we
componenttext: And I would just add that I also think Pall Mall will benefit, particularly on the East Coast, given some of the new contracts that we picked up with the Lorillard business as well as our new contract, with Newport included, should benefit Pall Mall as well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are there expenses we should be aware of in relation to the implementation of the new contracts around Q4 and Q1? Just want to make sure what sense as to any kind of initial cost maybe associated with this?
componenttext: Okay. Are there expenses we should be aware of in relation to the implementation of the new contracts around Q4 and Q1? Just want to make sure what sense as to any kind of initial cost maybe associated with this?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Nothing out of the ordinary.
componenttext: No. Nothing out of the ordinary.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a quick question, if I could, on Pall Mall. If you were characterize the promotional standing for Pall Mall, is it down the quarter or year-over-year? Is that one of the factors that's leading to, at least, the year-over-year adjustment -- reduc
componenttext: Okay. And a quick question, if I could, on Pall Mall. If you were characterize the promotional standing for Pall Mall, is it down the quarter or year-over-year? Is that one of the factors that's leading to, at least, the year-over-year adjustment -- reduction in market share?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Really nothing has changed on that front. We continue to have strong price realization on Pall Mall, but the promotion and the discounting levels of Pall Mall have been fairly consistent.
componenttext: No. Really nothing has changed on that front. We continue to have strong price realization on Pall Mall, but the promotion and the discounting levels of Pall Mall have been fairly consistent.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's really why we pointed out that it had been flat quarter-over-quarter. We lost this market share on Pall Mall, partly leading up to the acquisition, when we needed to put support dollars behind Winston-Salem and Kool. And so that is when some of
componenttext: And that's really why we pointed out that it had been flat quarter-over-quarter. We lost this market share on Pall Mall, partly leading up to the acquisition, when we needed to put support dollars behind Winston-Salem and Kool. And so that is when some of that share was lost. And then as I talked about, the whole sector is trading up a bit. So we're happy with where Pall Mall is, and there's no real change to promotional strategy.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just to reiterate, I think that's, really, what's driving Pall Mall is the environment has improved, and that's why you're seeing the trading up. And it is having some impact on Pall Mall, but it's not something that we're chasing.
componenttext: Yes. And just to reiterate, I think that's, really, what's driving Pall Mall is the environment has improved, and that's why you're seeing the trading up. And it is having some impact on Pall Mall, but it's not something that we're chasing.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta with Barclays.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I realize that it's going to take some time before your comfortable discussing these proceeds from Natural American Spirit and the international transaction. However, I was hoping you might be able to give us a little bit of perspective on how you think a
componenttext: I realize that it's going to take some time before your comfortable discussing these proceeds from Natural American Spirit and the international transaction. However, I was hoping you might be able to give us a little bit of perspective on how you think about potentially going about your deleveraging plans in conjunction with that? So as you think about your near-term maturity profile, is  sort of getting rid of that going to be more beneficial than potentially looking at the interest expense savings that might result from addressing some of your longer-dated bonds that have a higher coupon? And then also, how do you think about sort of the pricing on some of those bonds since taking out the final maturities could potentially be cheaper from a cost perspective versus the longer dated?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think at this point, I think it's just -- it's pretty mature. We're certainly going to be looking at all of the options and the use of the cash that will come in. But I think at this point, it's just premature to get into all of those sorts of disc
componenttext: Yes. I think at this point, I think it's just -- it's pretty mature. We're certainly going to be looking at all of the options and the use of the cash that will come in. But I think at this point, it's just premature to get into all of those sorts of discussions.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. Should we still be thinking about -- around $2.5 billion, maybe $2.75 billion of debt reduction as the objective over the next couple of years? Understanding that you guys are taking $450 million out in the coming days.
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. Should we still be thinking about -- around $2.5 billion, maybe $2.75 billion of debt reduction as the objective over the next couple of years? Understanding that you guys are taking $450 million out in the coming days.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, ultimately, the objective really is to get back to our balance sheet metrics that we feel are consistent with investment grade -- our investment-grade profile. So we're looking at a leverage ratio. As we've said, we want to operate between 1.5
componenttext: Yes. Well, ultimately, the objective really is to get back to our balance sheet metrics that we feel are consistent with investment grade -- our investment-grade profile. So we're looking at a leverage ratio. As we've said, we want to operate between 1.5 to 2.5x. So that is really what we've been looking at. Obviously, prior to this announcement, we talked about getting to 3x within 24 months. Certainly, that is still on our roadmap, and certainly, looking to get that achieved. And we'll be looking at the options to use the cash from the sale of the international business. And we'll have something more to speak to you probably down the road.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Milway with BlackRock.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Milway with BlackRock.

componenttext: Okay, I'll do that. Another question regarding the new 4 flavors for your VUSE brand. What are the expectations regarding the FDA in flavors going forward?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I'm sure you've read, the deeming regs have gone to the OMB. And so we don't know what they are yet, and that means they could come out soon or not. But we look forward to those deeming regs, and we will see what their position is across the cate
componenttext: Well, as I'm sure you've read, the deeming regs have gone to the OMB. And so we don't know what they are yet, and that means they could come out soon or not. But we look forward to those deeming regs, and we will see what their position is across the categories that we're waiting to hear. So it may be -- they will come out in due course, and we'll keep you posted.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just lastly, you've been talking about a branding to some more of the premium brands. Could you try to quantify that as far as what percentage you're seeing increase from the discounts to premiums?
componenttext: Okay. And just lastly, you've been talking about a branding to some more of the premium brands. Could you try to quantify that as far as what percentage you're seeing increase from the discounts to premiums?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if we look over a year ago, the premium are at 1.4% up versus a year ago. The premium mix is 71.4, and the year ago, it was 70. So we continue to see that inching up.
componenttext: Well, I think if we look over a year ago, the premium are at 1.4% up versus a year ago. The premium mix is 71.4, and the year ago, it was 70. So we continue to see that inching up.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Reynolds American Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Morris Moore, Vice President of Inves
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Reynolds American Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Morris Moore, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the third quarter and first 9 months as well as our revised full year outlook. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believ
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's result for the third quarter and first 9 months as well as our revised full year outlook. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believes this provides better perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release, which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com. Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO. 
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by Federal Securities Laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you know, it was a very busy quarter for us, and I'd like to start today with Reynolds American's result, which wrapped up a very strong first 9 months. Our net sales, earnings and margins were all signifi
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As you know, it was a very busy quarter for us, and I'd like to start today with Reynolds American's result, which wrapped up a very strong first 9 months. Our net sales, earnings and margins were all significantly higher in the third quarter, driven by excellent performance at our operating companies and the impact of Newport's addition to the R.J. Reynolds' portfolio. 
Adjusted industry cigarette volumes declined by 0.8% in the quarter, with continued growth in the premium cigarette category. In the moist snuff category, the environment remains competitive, and adult consumers continue to move back and forth between the various tobacco categories, modestly impacting the growth in moist snuff volume. As I've said before, our operating companies have a key advantage in offering a diversified product portfolio across tobacco categories with a range of distinctive brands at different price points. And this broad portfolio is also aligned with the key consumer macro trends that are driving brand choice. 
In addition, our company's strategy is to maximize the performance of the entire portfolio, with each of their key brand playing a distinctive role. Our companies are successfully managing this dynamic interplay between categories and between their key brands, and RAI is benefiting greatly from it. 
Of course, a major highlight of the quarter was the significant momentum on the Newport brand and its significant contribution to R.J. Reynolds' profitability. The integration of Newport, which was acquired in June, continues to go very well. The reciprocal contract manufacturing with ITG will continue until later next year, but the transfer of equipment to the Tobaccoville facility is well underway. 
Under the route-to-market agreement, no changes can be made to existing retail contract until the middle of next month, but R.J. Reynolds is currently selling in new retail contracts. And we're confident that Newport's expanded presence will drive further growth on the brand. 
The company's marketing and sales teams are also very focused on doing the necessary consumer research on Newport and identifying additional revenue opportunities for the brand as well as for the company's other growth brands, Camel and Pall Mall. Our employees are doing a great job with Newport's integration, and we're very happy with the way things are progressing. 
Before I give you more details on our operating performance, I'd like to update you on VUSE e-cigarettes, and then I'll cover a number of other recent developments. RJR Vapor's VUSE digital vapor cigarette continued to perform well in the third quarter and increased its #1 share position in the c-store channel. At the end of last month, 4 additional styles of VUSE cartridges were made available nationally. The brand now offers Crema, Mint, Berry and Chai, in addition to the existing original and menthol styles. Adult smokers have told our company's consumer engagement team that they are interested in having more options in addition to the traditional tobacco flavors, because they say that this could help them to switch to a smoke-free alternative like VUSE. 
Offering adult vapor a variety of options to consider is very much in line with our company's commitment to driving innovation, which is a key part of our transforming tobacco strategy. VUSE continues to invest in the development of a robust pipeline of innovation, and we'll be giving you more details on that at our Investor Day presentation in London and New York in November. 
As we announced late last month, manufacturing operations for VUSE have been consolidated at R.J. Reynolds' Tobaccoville facility, in line with the services agreement between R.J. Reynolds and RJR Vapor. And this will increase efficiencies as the vapor category and VUSE continue to develop. 
Moving onto some of the other headlines. In September, we announced the proposed sale of the Natural American Spirit business outside the U.S. to the JT Group for $5 billion. We believe it's a great deal. It will allow our companies to focus on brand growth here at home while the strength of JT Group's international capabilities will support the tremendous growth potential for Natural American Spirit overseas. I should note that this transaction still has to be approved by regulatory authorities in a number of countries, but that's expected to happen by early next year. And the transaction should close shortly thereafter. 
Another development was the signing of a technology-sharing term sheet between R.J. Reynolds and British American Tobacco, which provides a framework for collaboration and mutual cross-licensing of vapor product technologies through 2022. The companies are still negotiating specifics of the agreement, and they expect to reach a definitive contract by the end of this year. 
In addition, R.J. Reynolds and Santa Fe reached a settlement last week with the state of New York on the NPM disputed payments. The settlement resolved NPM adjustment claims encompassing 11 years and puts in place a new method of determining future adjustments from 2015 forward. We are very pleased to have reached a resolution on this long-standing dispute with New York. And as a result, the companies will receive significant value for the impact to their brands resulting from manufacturers who were not subject to the obligations of the master settlement agreement. R.J. Reynolds and Santa Fe will continue to pursue resolution of their NPM disputed payment claims against the remaining 27 states and other jurisdictions that have not yet settled with the company. 
As you know, there have also been developments on the regulatory front. In response to the FDA ruling that 4 of R.J. Reynolds' cigarette styles are not substantially equivalent to their respective predicate products, the company immediately stopped sales and notified trade partners of appropriate steps to stop further distribution, marketing and promotion of those products. R.J. Reynolds took the same action on Camel White style, because the products have the same characteristics as the Pall Mall style impacted by the ruling. 
I remind you that these cigarette styles represent a very small portion of R.J. Reynolds' business, and we believe R.J. Reynolds' brand will capture the majority of volume from the discontinued style. Let me reiterate that the company strongly disagrees with the FDA's ruling and is still examining all of its options. 
Now let's start the rest of our quarterly discussion, beginning with traditional cigarettes. Total RAI company's domestic cigarette volumes increased to 29.5% in the third quarter, significantly benefiting from the addition of Newport. Overall cigarette industry volume declined 2.2% for the quarter. When adjusted for wholesale inventory changes, industry shipments were down about 0.8%. Total RAI operating company's domestic retail market share also increased in the quarter by 0.3 percentage point to almost 34%. 
Focusing for a minute on R.J. Reynolds, I'm very pleased to report that the third quarter was very strong for the company. Adjusted operating income and margin were significantly higher, driven by an increase of over 30% in the company's cigarette shipments. I'd note that R.J. Reynolds' retail market share is presented on a pro forma basis, which reflects share information from the company's new brand portfolio, following the acquisition and the related divestiture. 
Reflecting these factors, R.J. Reynolds' total cigarette retail market share was down slightly from the prior year quarter at 32%. However, the company's expanded portfolio of growth brands, Newport, Camel and Pall Mall, added 0.2 percentage point in combined retail market share to 29.4% for the quarter. These brands now make up about 92% of the company's total cigarette market share. 
Even with the standstill in restrictions that I mentioned earlier, Newport is showing excellent momentum, with third quarter share of retail shipments increasing 0.5 percentage point from the prior year quarter to 13.3%. Camel's retail market share performance held steady in the quarter at 8.3%, and the company remains focused on initiatives to build the brand equity. 
Performance of R.J. Reynolds' Pall Mall value brand reflected the company's continued balance between share and profitability. The brand's retail market share was down 0.3 percentage point at 7.8% in the third quarter and was flat sequentially. 
As I'm sure you noticed in today's release, Santa Fe drove performance to new heights in the third quarter, with double-digit growth in volume and operating income. The company's highly profitable Natural American Spirit brand is successfully broadening awareness and trial beyond its traditional strong market in the Western U.S. And the brand reported retail market share of 1.9% for the quarter. That was up 0.3 percentage point from the prior year quarter. And Natural American Spirit's distinctive natural tobacco style grew volume by almost 20%. 
Now turning to moist snuff and American Snuff continued solid performance in a competitive market. The company, again, increased operating income with its flagship Grizzly brand, delivering higher volume and retail market share. American Snuff grew total moist snuff volume by 4.4%, which, again, outpaced industry growth of about 2.5% for the quarter. As a result, the company's moist snuff retail market share was up 1.3 percentage points from the prior year quarter at 33.7%. 
Grizzly delivered third quarter retail market share growth of 1.4 percentage points to almost 31%, and that was on volume growth of 4.6%. I'm pleased to say that Grizzly's reputation for offering innovative products continues. The brand's dark Wintergreen style, which was expanded nationally in March, is performing very well. 
So all in all, RAI's third quarter and 9 months have gone extremely well, and we continued to deliver excellent total shareholder return. And I'm especially pleased with the way that Newport's integration is progressing. 
So now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. Reynolds American and its operating companies had a great quarter, which included Newport's first full quarterly contribution earnings, and this resulted in a very successful first 9 months. RAI increased thir
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. Reynolds American and its operating companies had a great quarter, which included Newport's first full quarterly contribution earnings, and this resulted in a very successful first 9 months. RAI increased third quarter reported EPS by 4.5% from the prior year quarter to $0.46. On an adjusted basis, third quarter EPS was $0.55, up 17% from the prior year quarter. These results were supported by higher pricing and volumes across the board, the expiration of the federal tobacco quota buyout as well as continuous productivity improvements. 
Adjusted EPS excludes a charge of $0.04 per share for implementation costs and a charge of $0.05 per share for asset impairment and exit costs related to the consolidation of VUSE's manufacturing operations. 
RAI's 9-month reported EPS was $2.45, about double the prior year period. On an adjusted basis, 9-month EPS was $1.50, up more than 18%. Adjusted EPS excludes the items I've just mentioned as well as the gain on the divestiture, a benefit from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim, charges for transaction-related and financing costs, Engle progeny cases and tobacco-related and other litigation. RAI's third quarter adjusted operating margin jumped by 6.4 percentage points to almost 44.5%. 
Now I'll turn to our operating company's performance, where I'll discuss adjusted results where applicable. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results. 
As Susan said, R.J. Reynolds performed very well in the third quarter, with higher cigarette pricing and the expiration of the federal tobacco-quota buyout benefiting the bottom line, in addition to Newport's contribution. The company's reported operating income was $1.1 billion. Adjusted operating income increased by 64.6% from the prior year quarter to $1.2 billion. For the 9 months, R.J. Reynolds' reported operating income was $2.4 billion. 9 months adjusted operating income increased by more than 35% to $2.7 billion. The company's third quarter operating margin grew by 5.1 percentage points to 46.7%. And as Susan mentioned, the company's third quarter cigarette shipments were up 30.2% from the prior year quarter. 
Wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 7.6 billion units at the end of the third quarter, up about 600 million from the prior year quarter. R.J. Reynolds' inventory of approximately $2.3 billion were in line with the preceding quarter, reflecting the normalized level of the new cigarette portfolio. 
Before I move onto Santa Fe, I'd like to highlight the favorable impact from the settlement between the participating manufacturers and the state of New York on the NPM disputed payments. As a result of the settlement, R.J. Reynolds and Santa Fe will receive credits currently estimated to be approximately $290 million that will applied to the company's MSA payments over the next 4 years for its adjusted claims relating to the years 2004 through 2014. Additionally, the company may also receive credits based on a sliding scale keyed to the volume of non-state-excise-tax paid tribal sales in New York during the relevant market year. I'd note that since 2012, R.J. Reynolds has reached settlements in 24 jurisdictions on NPM adjustment claims related to the company's master settlement agreement payments. 
Now moving onto Santa Fe. Higher pricing and volume also boosted Santa Fe's earnings, and the company increased operating income by more than 23% from the prior year quarter to $120 million. That brought 9-month operating income to $337 million, which was up almost 37%. Santa Fe's third quarter operating margin also rose by 0.7 percentage point to more than 55%. It's worth noting that for the 9 months, the company reported operating margin of 55.5%. 
Now let's turn to American Snuff. The company increased third quarter operating income 3.4% to $121 million as higher pricing and volume more than offset the timing of marketing support activity. For the first 9 months, operating income rose almost 12.5% to $369 million. American Snuff's operating margin remained strong at 57.5% for the quarter. 
Before I turn to the Q&A, there are some other important items I want to mention. In line with the company's commitment to deleverage as quickly as possible while maintaining financial flexibility, we plan to pay down $450 million in debt that matures on Friday. At the end of the third quarter, our total long-term debt was $17 billion. 
I'd note again that we have a very manageable debt portfolio, which carries an average interest rate of 4.5% with an average maturity of 12.1 years. The company ended the quarter with cash balances of $2.9 billion. 
We remain deeply committed to returning value to our shareholders. And in that vein, I'd remind you of our 2-for-1 stock split in August as well as the most recent 7.5% dividend increase. 
So that finishes up our highly successful year-to-date. And as a result, we're tightening our full year adjusted earnings guidance to a range of $1.94 per share to $2 per share. Please note that this adjusted earnings guidance excludes all the items I mentioned at the beginning of my discussion. Thank you. 
Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bill Marshall with Barclays.

componenttextpreview: Actually, I just want to chew on a little bit, actually, on the technology-sharing agreement with BAT that you discussed. I don't believe that this agreement includes the heat-not-burn technology, if I'm not mistaken. So I just wanted to check on that. An
componenttext: Actually, I just want to chew on a little bit, actually, on the technology-sharing agreement with BAT that you discussed. I don't believe that this agreement includes the heat-not-burn technology, if I'm not mistaken. So I just wanted to check on that. And then on the past, you've kind of alluded towards developing maybe a Revo 2.0 or Eclipse 2.0 product. And I was curious, with a high hurdle to get a product like that, maybe out in the U.S. with the FDA restrictions, any reason why that wouldn't be included in this agreement with BAT and then something you could look to sell internationally to get it off the ground?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. The companies are still working out the definitive agreement. The top line term sheet was very much focused on vapor. Certainly, we are open to discussions when it comes to heat-not-burn. And you're not wrong in the context of using some of th
componenttext: Sure, Bill. The companies are still working out the definitive agreement. The top line term sheet was very much focused on vapor. Certainly, we are open to discussions when it comes to heat-not-burn. And you're not wrong in the context of using some of the innovation that we've already developed in heat-not-burn outside the U.S. will be quicker than getting it through our own FDA. So those possibilities are all still open to us. We're hoping to come to a definitive agreement by year end. And of course, we'll share the specifics with you.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Owen Bennett with Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Owen Bennett with Nomura.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So firstly, I was just wondering what changes you have been able to put into place with regards to driving the top line synergies of Camel and Newport, bearing in mind the marketing restrictions. Or are the share gains that we are seeing, is that just the
componenttext: So firstly, I was just wondering what changes you have been able to put into place with regards to driving the top line synergies of Camel and Newport, bearing in mind the marketing restrictions. Or are the share gains that we are seeing, is that just the existing underlying momentum before any change is put into place? And then secondly, how are you progressing with of the cost saves? And can you give an estimate of how much you expect to deliver in the current year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take the first one. We are delighted with Newport's momentum. It does seem to be accelerating, you're right. I mean, up half a share point over -- year-over-year. And we've not been able to change the merchandising. So as I mentioned in the pre
componenttext: Sure, I'll take the first one. We are delighted with Newport's momentum. It does seem to be accelerating, you're right. I mean, up half a share point over -- year-over-year. And we've not been able to change the merchandising. So as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, we are very encouraged that as we're selling in these retail contracts, that we'll be able to build this momentum once these contracts go into play. And remember, the contracts will probably take 3 to 4 months to set on a national basis, beginning in mid-November. Really, I would attribute the current momentum, yes, the brand came to us with natural momentum, but remember, we doubled the sales force overnight. And so I believe there's just more feet on the street looking out after Newport. And I'll hand over to Andrew on the synergies.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the cost savings, we're on track. As we've talked about $800 million worth of synergies. We've got $300 million we anticipate achieving over the first 18 months of the deal. So we're on track with that. There's obviously continued efforts to try a
componenttext: Yes. On the cost savings, we're on track. As we've talked about $800 million worth of synergies. We've got $300 million we anticipate achieving over the first 18 months of the deal. So we're on track with that. There's obviously continued efforts to try and accelerate and improve that number. We've incentivized the entire workforce to continue to look for those synergies and cost savings across the board. So we're on track. We feel good about that. We haven't provided a number for this year. But I would say that the majority of that $300 million is actually back-ended as that volume transitions out of the former Lorillard factory, now owned by ITG, and into our larger facility in Tobaccoville.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen and Company.

componenttext: Yes, I'll just start and then turn it over to Andrew, as necessary. I think you're absolutely right, we do have these regulatory approvals. We're not prepared at this stage to give specifics to those dollars, but we will certainly be coming forward with that as we approach the close.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Terrific. And then a question on the substantial equivalence and your decision to pull Camel Whites voluntarily. Do you feel like there's anything else in the system that could be at risk? Or do you feel like you've cleaned up the portfolio from an SE per
componenttext: Terrific. And then a question on the substantial equivalence and your decision to pull Camel Whites voluntarily. Do you feel like there's anything else in the system that could be at risk? Or do you feel like you've cleaned up the portfolio from an SE perspective?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, from those SE rulings, Vivien, we are totally clean. Those Camel White styles had similar -- the same characteristics as the ruling on the Pall Mall styles, and so that was the decision that we took. And as I stated, we disagree with the ruling
componenttext: Certainly, from those SE rulings, Vivien, we are totally clean. Those Camel White styles had similar -- the same characteristics as the ruling on the Pall Mall styles, and so that was the decision that we took. And as I stated, we disagree with the ruling. We will look forward to working with the FDA on the process. And we'll see where we go from here. But certainly, we are clean. And as you know, that combined market share was about 0.34. And as I stated, we do expect that we will recapture most of that volume with other styles in the family.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Terrific. That's very helpful. If I could just squeeze in one last one. Obviously, industry volumes continue to track very well. Susan, on the last call, you indicated that you thought industry volumes could be down 2%. So I was wondering if you could upd
componenttext: Terrific. That's very helpful. If I could just squeeze in one last one. Obviously, industry volumes continue to track very well. Susan, on the last call, you indicated that you thought industry volumes could be down 2%. So I was wondering if you could update that. And additionally, if you could offer any commentary at all on the volume trends that you're seeing in Hawaii, just because of the implementation of the new legal purchase age please.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll say, as we saw the quarter was down 2.2%, 0.8% on an adjusted basis, when we think about it, we are expecting -- if you look back over the years, and during the recessionary period, where people were mixing down, we saw 3% to 4% of cigarette de
componenttext: Sure. I'll say, as we saw the quarter was down 2.2%, 0.8% on an adjusted basis, when we think about it, we are expecting -- if you look back over the years, and during the recessionary period, where people were mixing down, we saw 3% to 4% of cigarette decline. And in the really strong years, we've seen, like this year, it's been particularly strong, where the economy -- we've had very good economic tailwinds for our consumers. But probably, the average of this 2% to 4% decline rate is where we should look as we go forward. And obviously, we report on that every quarter. We don't -- we have not yet been able to dissect Hawaii. As you know, it's a very small state, and we'll certainly look at those results. What's interesting and the perspective on that is that we have worked with the states for years to reduce underage smoking. And we've been very successful getting laws in place. The vast majority of volume that is used by underage is bought for them by adults. So the outcome of the 21 versus 18, I don't think we can see anything yet with that. There are better ways to address it. But having said that, that's the state's call. But we will be following that. And obviously, we'll be following if there's any other momentum as we go forward.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the COGS side, so -- I guess, I'm just trying to understand how the cost transferred to Imperial would have shown up in the quarter, because if I sort of look back at your base, RJR -- Reynolds' COGS and then add Lorillard's COGS, I'm getting kind of $574 million or $590 million.
